headline: Great Company to Work For
pros: Deloitte has great benefits, including 401(k) match, pension, health, and wellness subsidy.  PTO is accrued at a very reasonable rate, and there are generous holidays.  Deloitte expects employees to make the most of their time off, so your vacation time is expected to be away from work.  There is a pervasive attitude at Deloitte the what is best for your career is what is best for the firm.
cons: Deloitte is a high-performance firm, as such, the exception is that employees are high performance.  This can lead to long hours and high stress.

headline: Not a 40 hour p/week job
pros: Training, help attaining certifications, compensation, medical benefits, smart employees, global project opportunities, profitable company
cons: Utilization metrics reign supreme here. Even though you get "vacation" time, you pretty much have to make up most time off in order to hit required utilization targets. If you do not hit them, you do not get promoted, bonuses, pay raises, etc. In fact, you will be put on a Performance Improvement Plan even though your actual job performance may have been excellent.  Also, you must do a lot of  extra internal Deloitte work in addition to your project work.  Just keep in mind you will average about 50-60 hours per week when negotiating your salary.

headline: Wants to be cool but too risk averse to be cool
pros:
Deloitte employs smart people and has them engaged in a wide variety of projects. If you want to do public sector, health care, mobile development, mergers and acquisitions, technology platform implementations, or whatever else, you can do it all at Deloitte.

Deloitte University shows how Deloitte is putting its money where its mouth is in developing its people. Once I attended DU, I knew I had a company that was really trying to change the game in consulting.

There is a common sense that Deloitte Consulting is in the upswing and is clearly taking away work from all other consultancies whether they be strategy firms, digital agencies, or major platform implementers. Deloitte is also attracted people away from these other firms which speaks volumes to how people are perceiving Deloitte.
cons: Deloitte's roots are in audit and tax. Even though the majority of our revenue comes from consulting only, our culture and perception is seen as an audit and tax firm. Deloitte Consulting's leadership talks about innovation and is trying to do things differently but at the end of the day there is this engrained corporate culture of making slides for execs that are hard to read and 99% of them never see the light of day at the end of a project. If you look at how a startup or tech company operates, they do things. They follow agile principles and realize that a public product is better than extensive documentation. This is not the approach Deloitte takes.

headline: Consultant
pros:
1. Progression is almost guaranteed for the first 5 years - up to Manager level.

2. Highly social organisation with an unusually high concentration of very strong, generalists, especially at the more junior levels. You can develop relationships with hundreds of people that will go on to operate all aspects of Ireland Inc. over the next 10 years.

3. Decent (but pretty limited) exit opps. For S&O, most consultants move into Sales or Customer Success at a tech company. For Tech/Digital, most consultants go into analytics or engineering elsewhere. If you stick around long enough to become a Manager (5-6 years) you have significantly more options available.
cons:
1. Performance appraisal, bonuses, and promotions are based on management's opinion of you which is vulnerable to manipulation, bad actors, and incompetence.  

2. Management do not receive training in people management so ability varies wildly. Additionally, performance appraisal is 100% based on your superiors' opinions, so weak people managers routinely blame their shortcomings on external factors and get away with it.

3. Majority of staff are effectively "leased out" to a bank for several years, gaining very little useful experience, no development of commercial acumen, and earn significantly less than the bank would have paid them as an employee.

4. Salaries are *significantly* below standard. I've heard of Consultants/SCs doubling their salary after leaving. Even with a top performance rating (0-1% of staff per year) the bonuses are insultingly low.

5. A strong culture of dishonesty, "spinning", salesmanship, and saying one thing while doing another. Very little domain knowledge from senior staff. Zero rigour or planning applied by staff below Director level.

6. Firm rewards action for the sake of action. Heavy bias to moving fast and attacking problems with the first thing that comes to mind, rather than trying to find the right solution before acting.

7. No analytical or quantitative acumen in Consulting, with the exception of Analytics

8. The firm leans very heavily on the reputations of the US and UK firms. "Strategy and Operations" in Ireland is really "Sales and Project Management." Most staff in this division could make significantly more money doing the same job elsewhere with an honest job title.

9. Culture is viewed as marketing nonsense and is poorly conceived. For example: "an unwavering commitment to each other" is a deeply inappropriate value for a professional services firm. If I make a mistake in a regulated business I need to know my colleagues will hold me to account, not help me bury the body.

headline: Deloitte's a good firm, but partnership structure creates a highly negative two-caste organization
pros: Big, lots of different paths that can be taken within the organization.  Firm has global reach, and lots of very bright and hard-working people.  It will never hurt your resume to have a stint with Deloitte on it.  The firm is by and large well intentioned, and generally comes out on the right ethical side of the issues.  Senior management genuinely wants to make it a friendly place for people of all types and grades, but they don't always know how to bring this off successfully.  Generally speaking, the firm attempts to do things in a first-class way, more or less.
cons: The partnership structure creates an artificial and highly negative two-caste culture and mentality in the organization.  The partners by and large make way too much money:  in the private sector, most of them would have to take a 50% pay cut or more.  Additionally, there is an excessive emphasis on billable hours, selling, bringing in revenues, which is at odds with the desire of the organization to continue being viewed as "different" from an ordinary "business" -- to be thought of as professionals acting in the public good.  (That said, though, the organization mostly does make a positive contribution to, e.g., the transparent and fair functioning of the capital markets.)

headline: Overhyped
pros: Benefits are great, work is challenging, clients are huge, offices are nice, internal processes and systems are good, people are sharp

Broad brush review, but:

As an industry expert with a good reputation on projects, I have been super unimpressed by partners at this firm. Interviewed with all the best consultancies and chose Deloitte for the reputation and training I’ll be provided, but I made a mistake. The culture is shaped by the leaders, and the leaders don’t care about their people. Read the constructive posts. The people at this company don’t like to work together. They like to compete.

headline: Glass cieling closes-in quickly when PPE goes down!

Then, they make excellent PPD candidates who are otherwise more than qualified go through the process a SECOND time! Sucky way for PPD group to show appreciation for folks who drop everything and travel around the world to work 16 hour days and make them boatloads of cash.

headline: Stay in your place!
pros:
Excellent benefit package. 

Opportunity to build lasting relationships - Deloitte has some wonderful, creative, intelligent employees. Really the best at what they do. Network, network, network. 

Great place to hone your political skills
cons:
There are distinct classes within Deloitte - generally Deloitte Services is second class - expect some internal clients in the Functions (Tax, Audit, Consulting, etc.) to treat you like a servant rather than a teammate. Deloitte Services leadership is not so great at advocating for its team members or supporting them in client situations. 

Huge volume of communications work, and lots of demand, but nature of that communications work is repetitive and formulaic, focused mainly on process and compliance with protocols. For everything you will produce, there is a script and a scripted process. Don't expect to be stimulated. Overworked, yes. Engaged, no. 


Work/life balance is very difficult to achieve. Actual support (in actions, rather than lip-service) for work/life balance is...elusive.  

Leadership has not figured out how to foster teambuilding and help employees feel connected in its increasingly virtual environment. Especially when said teams are scattered across the country/globe. 

Pay is middling. Bonus, virtually nonexistent.

headline: Perfect place to be if you're under thirty. If not.....not so much.
pros: Excellent benefits, excellent pay, many project opportunities to choose from. Cutting edge technology. Can perform many roles.  Well known as number one Big 4 firm.
cons: Extremely cliquish. If you don't know anyone be prepared to rot on bench and then get chewed out about utilization being low. Work life balance is pitiful. Plenty of HR nonsense about health and welfare of employees, not followed on projects. Must be able to meet any day and any night.  Most upper level stuck in 1980 employee employer relationships. Very few Americans in tech advisory, they don't hire many natives. Lots of BS brown nosing required at office even after traveling all week. Required to be in office on Friday even if on opposite coast the rest of the week.   No control over assignments but still required to keep utilization extremely high.  Be prepared to have a coach who doesn't work in your area and or doesn't have a clue about your skill set.

headline: Brainwashed!
pros:
You can work with some really dedicated, honest, amazing people who care about their jobs.  Some of the  senior managment seem to care. 
Flexibility, sense of not really reporting to anyone.  Automony.
Some good folks all over the company that work to support you.
cons:
You become brainwashed that all this is normal.

1.) You forget why you wanted to quit when you started - get caught up in deloitte family while your family grows, laughs, develops on their own.  You  start to think 50-70hrs is normal.
2.) Success all about timing/right place at right time/who you work for/when to say no.
3.) Experienced hires get little respect/any training while homegrown get specialized training and are promoted at alarmingly fast paces and leads to future problems not addrsed.
4.) Harrassment - countless stories and witness to bad behavior/ frequent put downs/insults.
5.) Internal competition doesnt create a "conducive" work environment - breaks down groups.
6.) Sales - rainmaker - not in my undergrad/cpa training. "Break the rules" 
7.) Egomaniacs - see item 4.

headline: Great Company to start a career

headline: Play the politic.s
pros: Coming in at a junior level, if you're half decent and care for your career, you will quickly be put in roles above your pay grade. You will quickly learn the core consulting skills you need to succeed anywhere. There are some exceptionally bright people that you can work with and learn from.
cons: Work is life, there is no balance - i'm paraphrasing what was said during my orientation, and it's true at Deloitte. To 'succeed' here, you will need to be a workaholic. You will also need to know how to work the politics to grow in the firm. The compensation is sub-par, the culture isn't healthy in the long run, and middle management is a joke. The senior management level is staffed with some great people, but the levels in are less so for the most part.

headline: If you know better, do better
pros:
Excellent benefits and paid time off
Commitment to diversity and inclusion
cons:
If you are a female, middle-aged and have been with Deloitte 15+ years, beware of economic down-turns. 
Laid off during COVID and then scrambled to rehire - very reactive and uncaring approach.
Lots of talk about work-life balance, not practiced very often.
Internal roles are not valued and is reflected in annual merit increases averaging 2-3% and annual bonuses averaging 2-3%.
Little room for career advancement outside of client service focused roles.

headline: Good for career but job environment isn’t worth it
pros:
* Resume builder (it is a 'big 4' firm after all) 
* Staff and seniors are generally, although not always, a young group of  fun hardworking people
* Structured career progression (vs. industry)
* Depending on how many clients you have, you're not necessarily stuck at one place with the same group of people all year. So you get nice little changes of environment every few months or so (although that starts to go away at the Senior level)
* Vacation time is great. And you're able to use all of it, in the Portland office anyways. 
* Hours during the summer are good. Not too busy. 
* Portland office is a good size (big yet small) so you get to know most everyone
* Client base is diverse
cons:
* You definitely feel like a resource/body to be used by those above you sometimes 
* Management is not interested in creating a work environment for people to stay long term. Staying beyond 1-4 years is crazy even for someone who loves auditing and has great clients and support systems. It takes a super ambitious person who is willing to put up with a lot of downsides to stick it out and management is not interested in improving any of those downsides. From talking with my friends at other firms, this is pretty consistent across public accounting in general. 
* Pay is low and you can leave at almost every level for much higher pay for lower hours. Deloitte was the lowest paying of the larger firms in my city and raises/bonuses were poor. 
* Work-life balance during a big chunk of the year is awful
* Audit Quality and Audit efficiency are conflicting goals. So you often end up in no-win situations where there is really nothing you can do to make your partner/manager happy. 
* People eat time all of the time. Managers/Partners know but don't really care and reduce budgets every year and then hold staff to those budgets. 
* Office politics
* It feels like a pretty thankless job

headline: Good corporate culture, with a lot of employee learning and development focus but too many managers

- Average and sometimes competitive compensation packages
- Very good benefit packages and maternity/ paternity leaves.
cons:
- Too much bureaucracy and favoritism. 
- Its not what you do, its who you know to grow in this organization, all this is secretly swept under the shadow of the notion of "networking". its too political. 
- Too many managers and senior leadership, which makes it very hard and challenging to grow in this company. 
- Too much work for the pay, you will end up working 10 hours almost daily handling multiple teams and audit clients daily. 
- Extremely high expectations from Partners. 
- An astounding number of lunch meetings, breakdown meetings, war rooms etc.

headline: Senior Consultant
pros: Amazing place to work at the start of your career.  Some Partners and Directors had all the time in the world to coach you.  Learnt a lot of great content, how to structure problem solving, facilitate workshops and create and deliver client-centric solutions. Really valuable learning!
cons: Very hierarchical. It was very opaque as to how to progress and very much a 'trust me'  or 'we know it when we see it' approach rather than a "goal + objective feedback + results" approach.  While goals were set, the delivery of these against feedback and coaching was all over the place. No one person had accountability for helping you which watered down the value of these reviews and feedback.

headline: A good place to work- for a finite period.
pros:
- Great Colleagues
- Some cool trips throughout the year 
- Good place to learn and grow quickly
- Good name on the CV
- Extensive exposure to some of the biggest companies in the world
- Good starting salary
cons:
- Work-life balance takes a massive hit. As a result, people often stay long enough to gain some great skills then move onto somewhere more "regular" (1.5/2 year mark). 
- Bonus scheme does not properly reward overtime- average roughly 45 (reported) hours a week, but bonus is linked to overall business performance rather than just individual time and effort. 
- If you don't know how to set boundaries you will burn out.

headline: Deloitte Consulting's Business Analyst Program is one of the best
pros: Deloitte Consulting's high growth in Strategy & Operations consulting translates to a large number of career and personal development opportunities and a tight-knit culture (you know almost every S&O practitioner in your office).  I have attended a large number of cutting-edge conferences, adventure outings, international service trips, wine tastings, etc., all on Uncle D's dime.  Compared to other consulting firms, the Business Analyst program has better leadership, career, and personal opportunities.
cons: High uncertainty and ambiguity can leave folks disoriented if they don't adapt easily.  New grads who didn't enjoy leading extracurricular programs in college will not find a good fit with the BA program.

headline: Good place to start but don't expect to last long
pros:
=- benefits are really good
- you get a lot of hotel points
- most of the People are a lot of Fun
- BIG4 really is a good stepping stone in your career
cons:
All the stars have to align in order for you to enjoy your time there. You have to have a good team, an in town job, and a client that cares/values you. Without it, you'll burn out and won't be happy there.
- work a ton of hours (7 days a week)
- very little flexibly without taking time off (until you're a manager and outside of October-April)
- pay isn't great considering how much you work
- "travel" consists of going to small towns in Wisconsin 80%+ time of the year
- raise/reward system is flawed

headline: What a nightmare!
pros: The pay was good... sort of... Once you start working there and realize the mental hell, office politics, clicky drama, and ridiculous workload senior managers dump on you the pay was not that great.
cons: Horrible place to work! To use the term high stress would be a complete understatement. Senior managers just dump work on you, no training, no support. Definitely witnessed a better work environment for men but even then I saw male employees be treated really badly. People there on all levels only care about themselves and no one speaks up to protect team members. It is a culture of everyone for themselves. Just awfully place honestly, all they care about is money and the client. They pretend to care about talent but actually only care about the client/money.

headline: Not worthy of it's high rankings for 'Best Places to Start Career'
pros: Vast opportunities to interact with senior management of the client very early in your career.  You learn very early how to handle yourself professionally and learn the business vernacular.
cons:
Demands are often unrealistic and frustrating.  Not everyone loves to audit all day long (and into the evenings), but oftentimes seniors and/or managers expect it from you, as they impose their feelings onto you.
Promotions and raises are very political, and it seems there is a lot of time given up by employees to receive minimal compensation from the partners (although there is generally high praise, which dissipates quickly)

headline: Full bla bla culture
pros:
Brand name and infrastructure facilities are good. Also you will have enough team or account level outings or parties. 
Good pay package.
cons:
WFH is a garb to ensure your 24/7 or late night and early morning availability, forget your personal life.
Work quality is not good.
You should be good in communication no matter how bad you are at your work.
High politics at every level, cut throat competition and unrealistic deadlines.
Managers consider themselves god, will literally threaten you for ratings and would politely screw you if otherwise.
You can forget your skills, your demands would never be heard for a change of project.
"Cool", " Dude", "Yupp" are the official words here - the deloitte culture words and too much of buttering required for you to be promoted and yes I have seen it happening plenty across projects.
Many managers on you to make you confused whom to listen to.
If you don't know your work, that is fine, but you should be good in making slides. 
Mundane and outdated work of mostly federal clients in US using legacy systems.

headline: A great beginning point
pros: Loads of exposure to many types of clients, projects, trainings, resources/tools, and generally surrounded by very bright individuals. Although I’ve had previous work experience prior to joining the firm, this is my first opportunity to really become a jack of all trades. It’s impressive how many new skill sets they support in the form of DU training, webinars, classes, project opportunities, and/or specialized trainings (i.e., for newcomers or military veterans). All in all, it’s a wonderful firm to learn and develop in whichever general field you’d like, in whatever account(s) of interest, or area of practice you’re already skilled in or want to grow. Deloitte has a global reach and the resources to support almost anything you want to do.
cons:
The nature of consulting often seems like one’s knowledge is a mile wide, but only an inch deep. Not that it’s impossible to become a SME, but until years and years of experience and self-branding, it’s difficult to get projects lined up that truly allow continuity and deep growth in a particular area of interest. There’s just a lot of turn over with projects and it can be frustrating to always feel behind the learning curve with constant “newness”. To be clear, this is also truly amazing to be constantly learning brand new skills, processes, methodologies, etc, however, it’s tough when you know where you want to grow/develop, but it gets put on hold because that project/client/ role may not be available when you are. I often want more time to be stable in a role and become an expert in my field of interest. Unfortunately, I’ve learned that to gain this expertise and to ensure project opportunities in the Deloitte account I’m interested in, I will have to leave the firm to gain that knowledge and then come back eventually. 

Work/life balance can be a struggle sometimes.

People are brilliant here, however the company culture sometimes cultivates trust issues among employees, fierce competition, and superficial ick.

headline: Mostly positive but its still consulting...
pros: Competitive pay, bonuses, and benefits.  Constant training and opportunity to learn and improve.  Most colleagues and associates are solid and hard working.
cons: Travel constantly;  they say you can work on the projects you are passionate about however, the reality is you do what you are assigned... you get little to no real influence on where you are assigned.  Promotions requirements are not all that clear, just depends on whom you ask.  Worklife balance is so so - depends on the project and the lead. Politics are constant and competition is always apparent - you have to be good at selling yourself and talking your work up in order to be recognized. It doesn't end at project work, firm contributions are a big part of the job and take a lot of time and focus.

headline: 20% of
pros:

4. Monetary rewards every month paid out but that too would be if you have contacts. Same people get those rewards every month.
cons:
1. Leadership not so transparent as they show on surface.
2. Very poor work - all junk work in support from US. Implementation projects can be good.
3. Poor rating and appraisal system. No transparency.
4. They will low-ball you and give you below expected hikes.
5. You have to do thousands of other things apart from work to get a promotion.
6. No transport facilities or shift allowance.
7. Hiring like anything and, so hikes are going down. In few years, it will be just like any other IT company.
8. No onsite.

headline: great, solid place to start your career
pros: Deloitte will provide you with key, solid core consulting skills through its solid training programs and on-the job training / apprenticeship model.  The people at Deloitte are collegial, smart, and team-based.  You develop and nurture a strong network of business folks who are successful, whether at Deloitte or whether they have moved on to other areas.  Definitely a great place to start and grow a career.
cons: Deloitte is a HUGE firm - it is a full-service global firm, which means it provides audit, tax, and consulting services.  You can then imagine how bureaucratic the firm can get, with lots of management layers within and between organizations, geographies, industries, etc.

headline: Audit Assistant Manager
pros:
Great offices and facilities. Newly built HQ which is pretty special, even for audit staff (it's mainly for clients and their associated key revenue-generating departments, like consulting and advisory).
Access to the best and biggest clients in the world, something you don't get outside Big 4 accounting firms
ACA fully funded
Phone scheme is very cheap
Prestigious name for your CV
Excellent training as far as Graduate schemes go
Good hours outside busy season and ability to work from home
Opportunities to move internally or externally so you're never trapped (after you finish your ACA!)
Job security. Never heard of anyone being fired for anything other than gross misconduct
cons:
Seen as a 'departure lounge' in audit. Most people don't stay beyond their first 4 years. The presumption of this leads to a clear lack of motivation across the department
The pay is poor relative to other FS jobs. It's also the lowest of the Big 4. No proper bonuses. Work twice as hard as someone else and they'll give you £600 in your first year
A LOT of time at the client site - I hated not being able to get into a proper routine / cycle to work / go to the gym

headline: Good big picture values, not so great at the daily things that really matter.
pros: Great benefits (PTO, flexibility, etc.), good opportunities to travel & get a feel for the consulting lifestyle. Projects & clients can be very interesting and you'll meet a lot of intelligent and interesting people within your teams.
cons: The HR and hiring department/project reassignment assistance is practically useless. They are of really no help - it's all down to you and your networking abilities to find a new project once you roll off or a previous project ends. I'm honestly unsure what exactly the resource managers are getting paid to do, at least since the ones I know have been of zero help.

headline: Experienced Audit Staff
pros:
1. Steep learning curve: You will be expected to know a lot with minimal to NO guidance. Training sessions are just there to please HR with no actual knowledge being imparted. This is a plus because somehow the best employees end up self-learning and excel.

2. Assistant Managers and below are more humble and friendly. Some are willing to take time to teach new staff who have no experience.
cons:
1. Promotions and ratings are very biased. Some under-performing staff were promoted consistently due to having political connections. Some staff who delivered quality work in a timely manner get ignored simply because they are deemed "replaceable".

2. Job scope is highly inaccurate. You are expected to perform AUDIT work. Yet, somehow managers take advantage of staff below them to do ADVISORY and work that do not appear in the job scope.

3. Those holding positions above Assistant Managers often refuse to even talk to low-leveled staff and this often creates a lag between reviewing work and work done. This also causes new staff to be demotivated and often under perform.

4. Human Resources somehow do not value audit staff. They are often ignored and sometimes the leave system has problems as HR leave days and audit booking days could clash.

cons:
See above in terms of travel: you have very little say in where you end up, and sometimes you're there for 12+ months at a time
EXTREMEMLY political, and difficult to get highly rated or a promotion unless you're chummy with sr. management and partners
Do not expect to have a social life if you're single, unless you're interested in hooking up with colleagues on the road (which I was NOT)

headline: Consultant (Monitor Deloitte)
pros: Good brand value and career jump opportunities. Stable infrastructures and work locations. Ambitious colleagues, diverse project opportunities with big names.
cons: Poor pay, takes advantage of first-job hires, knowing they are here for the name and career jump. Pays well only to top seniors with equity.

headline: Spread too thin
pros: Opportunities to get involved in new projects, business development opportunities, and to upskill through training and conference attendances (virtually these days!)
cons:
The firm is ambitious and seeks, like many others, to get more from less. It spreads itself and its people too thin, is unable to truly become an expert in something, and will expect non-chargeable work like business development to be done no matter how many days a week you're spending on chargeable projects. Your 35 hour week contract is never met and your days are hugely fragmented. Partners not always present. It's a sink or swim company.

It's pushing a big, aggressively liberal left-modernist agenda on people, changing its in-house assessment criteria based on race, and has gone overboard on diversity and inclusion. It's getting folks down and ruffling feathers with the constant training / messaging.

headline: Great name for your resume - Good luck getting out of there alive
pros:
- Ahead of the curve in competitive intelligence
- Progressive professional training library and Deloitte University
cons:
- If you're not a Partner, you never will affect the focus
- Company will do ANYTHING to make Region 10 successful (India) including highjacking work  completed in the US and attributing to the India office
- Colleagues will literally throw anyone under the bus in order to keep their job
- Place zero value on human life and will use you up and spit you out
- Never will be a league with management consulting even though they think they are competing with McK, BCG, or Bain
- Partnership really is Us vs. Them; they may offer salary plus bonus but NEVER pay out

headline: Poor management / insufficient training
pros: CAN be a relaxed environment; little micromanagement in the beginning; firm presents itself with rose colored glasses.
cons: Management was very poor, they were never in sync with each other, everybody you asked a question to gave you a completely different answer which is very strange for a LAW firm... They give you little training for a new project and turn around and expect you to know exactly what you’re doing, and if you don’t they won’t tell you, they’ll email everybody on the team and leave everyone wondering who they’re talking about. When my manager had a problem with somebody she would never tell you directly to your face. Just threaten everybody to be taken to HR. Management is too pretentious. Even the lowest position is work that requires thought and extensive training, yet are entirely underpaid given the fact that they are given other people’s work on top of their own. They will lure you in with colorful walls, “game rooms” and free donuts, but don’t be fooled, behind the pretty wallpaper is just another dull, pretentious, poorly managed law firm.

cons:

2) Project Management is sometimes chaotic
3) If you have skill A if you're lucky you will be put into good projects with that skill. Having said that, chances are higher where you will be put into projects that you not comfortable with. You will be forced to work on it.

headline: Great Internship
pros: Deloitte has unparralled reputation for it's work/life balance lifestyle. Deloitte can pay its employees lower because of its great culture. At Deloitte, people make a concerted effort to make you feel great. They also really believe that you can bring value to the company, even as an intern. Therefore, you will see Deloitte senior managers helping an intern on an engagement. Furthermore, Deloitte is place where people really value fun. They believe that they can work you hard, but also allow you to play hard. At Deloitte, people are valued as people and not as numbers, sales, charts. They respect you.
cons: Deloitte can be a little stuffy sometimes. Also, it can appear as if people aren't as smart as you. Many of these things can be overcome.

headline: Good place to start career, but unsure about staying long-term
pros: Learning from smart people, flexibility to try different client projects, benefits like $500 wellbeing subsidy has been great. Travel perks were also pretty good before COVID. Once you find a good network, they can be very supportive throughout your career
cons:
Very network-based, and performance is basically evaluated on how much your manager likes you and your ability to stay staffed on client projects. Being evaluated on a scatterplot of your peers (all of which who have managers that evaluate their talent differently) is really misleading and honestly not helpful to my development.

Having long hours is standard, like most consulting firms. You have to suss out which partners / SMs tend have more intense projects and pursue staffing opportunities accordingly. Even though it has been acknowledged that people are feeling burnt out during the pandemic from constant Zoom meetings, nothing has really changed significantly to fix it.

Also, GSAP is a lot more selective than in the past, even though it's marketed heavily when recruiting candidates. I recently found out I wasn't eligible because my performance wasn't "exceptional", even though I feel like I went above and beyond over the past 2 years, so that's extremely demotivating. Compensation is relatively average

pros: Collegial,  Hard working, Process and Structure, Lots of Smart and experienced professionals
cons:
One of the main value and selling point a career at Deloitte suggests is the ability to establish a career and have stability for work/life balance.  As there is continued price and margin pressure, the company isresorting to more and more squeezing additional billing hours and reducing overhead costs to remain competitive. 
this push and aim to go to the lowest possible cost is causing significant distress and suggests that a new business model needs to be rethought.

headline: A great place to start a career, with plenty of opportunities for continued professional success.
pros: Deloitte offers a wealth of professional opportunities, which really is only limited by the individual's interest and effort in pursuing those opportunities to grow.  I have had the opportunity to work with some of the largest companies in the world on projects of critical importance to those organizations.  The collaborative spirit of the firm provides ample opportunity to work on these projects with company representatives and other Deloitte professionals at all levels.  I think that this combination of great client project opportunities and the chance to work in a collegial team environment makes Deloitte a great place to work, both as a career launch pad, but also as a long-term career choice.
cons: Networking is incredibly important, and it can be difficult at times to connect with the right people within different disciplines without an informal, personal link.  One of the great strengths of the firm is the diverse skill sets and perspectives, and although there are more formal reporting lines and "proper" channels for working across disciplines, but informal networking often is the real way that work gets done.  This may serve as an advantage once you are able to develop those networks (and a better understanding of what other services and skills are available within Deloitte), but it can be frustrating if you urgently need to identify a particular skill set outside of your network.

headline: Observations
pros: Diversity, Equity and Inclusion: promotes and enacts an inclusive work environment. Regardless of your background, history, gender, cultural values, beliefs, etc., Deloitte prides itself on welcoming practitioners from all walks of life in the firms best effort to create a positive work environment for their employees.
cons: Though Deloitte has made a better effort to enhance their practitioners work-life balance, work expectations are challenging and oftentimes require individuals to be responsible for many facets of the job. While this is a great way to instill positive leadership qualities, it can often lead to high stress and periods of burn out. Additionally, mid-level management/managers, at least the ones I've worked for, don't always take it upon themselves to establish a "sub-culture" within their teams, appearing 'cold' and don't promote comradery to the best of their ability.

2.Your US counterpart will do half your work and get double your salary .
3.You have to login at odd hours and will have to come online at 3am if you get a call from manager .

headline: If you are looking for a place to learn how to work, wrong place.
pros: Brand name on my resume
cons: Unrealistic expectations, poor training, impossible to change the service line (if you would like to try another service line within Deloitte, not going to happen). New staff, be prepared to use the copier machine and scanner a lot during you first years at Deloitte because that's all you are going to do! Most of the interesting work from level I and II is being sent to India so the projects can be done at a lower price for the client. As a consequence, the new staff is not getting any work that will help them develop their technical skills. Management knows the new staff is not being trained but they could not care less.

pros:

Poor female representation in consulting; becomes hard to progress after you have a child 
Partners are not incentivised to be creative or to innovate, so although the investment in innovation is a great step forward, the incentives structure needs to be reviewed.

headline: Ahead of the curve
pros: I think for the size of the company and nature of the business (consulting, tax, auditing), Deloitte is really ahead of the curve in terms of compensation, wellness, and social change. Deloitte adapts very quickly and I can feel in their communications to employees they care about social issues and want to empower individuals to own their careers/well-being.
cons: More realistic comp adjustments compared to the market for certain cities would be appreciated. Denver, Chicago, LA, New York; cities like this comp is still not caught up to the cost of living.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Deloitte is an overall great place to work.  The work is challenging and fulfilling, and the general employee population is highly capable.  Pay and benefits are good and the firm genuinely cares about its employees.  I've been able to form great relationships and develop an impressive network in industry and within the firm.  At a minimum, Deloitte is a great place to launch your career and learn critical well rounded skills needed in the business world.
cons: In return for great pay and benefits, the work and travel can be very demanding.  To be the best, significant personal sacrifice is required.  Compensation varies significantly based on your performance rating history.

headline: Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu in Japan is in relaity TOHMATSU (A Japanese Corporation)
pros:
The importance is set heavily upon WORK/LIFE Balance. We have the freedom to get off on time without the added pressure of needing to stay because your bosses are staying late. Most often than not the partners (if not your immediate boss) will be ushering you out the door as the Bell tolls for end of day (this bell thing is totally Japanese it rings twice a day morning to start, evening for end of day).

As the down turn of the market suggest lack of "quality work" the work for consulting firms are limited. There is really no "real work" to be done as the company itself is struggling to get work with competition from PWC, KPMG, and E&Y. Our division in particular is also fighting to grab jobs pitting against internal departments. Overall, most of the time is spent idling by on the company issued laptops using our free time for studies (such as CPA, CFA, GMAT). The freedom to use time on your own is abundant and is greatly geared towards married women who want to earn extra income, struggling artists, or people who need a relaxing environment to suppor themselves before commiting to a graduate degree (although the pay is significantly small and lacking time is in excess).

Job Security is impecable, as with most Japanese firms firing employees are frowned upon. It reflects badly upon the managers if an employee quit or are fired. No one is fired therefore, even if a perosn is caught sleeping on the side no downsides. Overall if you want job security of NEVER getting fired or need a 9-5 job to support your artistic or struggling main career or perhaps a house wife wanting to come back to the work force it is a very inviting place. They are even willing to take back employees who once quit more so than outsiders.
cons:
One will be eternally bored if you are use to working for your pay. The concept of work is used excessively and very loosely. No one seems to mind that new hires come in every month as the division is putting out losses. The no stress and no work environment may come to some as an upside, but for over achieving individuals who would like recognition for their work is lacking. Recognition is only given to those on higher levels (much like Japanese corporations) and not necessarily to the individual who achieved the load.

No set career path. As with in most Japanese corporations, there is no "Set" career path for anyone. You are brought on as a generalist which is a good idea for developed groups, but not for a company who prides itself on specialist professionals. Without any direction junior personnel is bounced to and from numerous ares without much of a career in any one specific field. Which in return makes them an unfit candidate for jobs which require specialists with individual professional traits required for an Audit/Accounting firm. For individuals at a Junior Level this company is highly advised aginst unless you are content with doing multiple tasks that may not lead to a specialist area, and nothing to add to your CV.

headline: You gotta love what you do!
pros:
The Environment at DD is not for anyone. To truly thrive you need to be a go getter, dedicated to your craft. You need think, read, and learn about your craft not just for the 8 hours you are at work. If you are a designer you need to see the world from that perspective all the time. If you are a tester you need to have that curious mind all the time. You need to do what you do because you love what you do, not simply for the paycheck every two weeks.

From a professional development stand point you can go anywhere you want in DD. While you are expected to excel at your current discipline, once you’ve shown that ability you are free to soak up any knowledge you desire. I have seen testers become Project Managers and Developers, Developers become Project Managers and Engagement Managers, and many other discipline changes. 

Senior Leadership’s ability to empower their people and give them the tools to make great works can sometimes be seen as lack of leadership; this is far from the truth. In a non-micromanaged environment it’s the motivated and best of the best that are going to thrive; why would you want to work next to anyone else?
cons: Going from a 150 person company to ~200k comes with serious growing pains. Do more to make us feel like the 150 again. You've pretty much taken our Übermind away, the replacement needs to be as fun.

headline: Poor pay but nice working environment and great sense of community
pros:
1) Good work-life balance. You only have to deliver the work assigned, so if you're quick you can leave early. We had long lunch breaks. Never worked more than 9 hours per day, never worked during week-ends but I understand that it depends on client and department.
2) 25 days leave and you can buy 5 additional days
3) Lots of social events, dinners, sponsored activities, free gym, free yoga courses, presents for staff
4) Great training opportunities
5) Great IT support, new laptops, new mobiles, whatever you need and want.
6) Open-door atitude.
cons:
1) Very low salary. I got promoted twice but the total salary increase was £ 1,000 (yes, one thousand only). That's a joke folks!
2) No bonus irrespective of appraisal, again, not happy!
3) Everybody can be replaced.

headline: Consultant

headline: Very poor performance, well below expectations
pros:
- Access to high-level clients early in the career
- Opportunity to work on challenging and decisive projects
- Opportunity to work in various sectors
cons:
- No effort for the well-being of employees
- Uninteresting job consisting of very repetitive tasks
- Enormous workload reaching 100 hours per week, including on Saturday and Sunday
- Unpaid overtime
- No recognition for the hard work
- Funnel-shaped managerial structure with many managers, directors and partners but no juniors to do the time-consuming work
- They are management consultants, but there is a clear lack of management skills
- "Diviser pour mieux régner"
- Bonus is very small
- Unequal opportunity employer
- Very difficult to take vacations
- Management expects you to stay available in the middle of the night

headline: Deloitte India lacks behind its USI counterpart
pros:
Pros in Deloitte India
1. Direct interaction with clients
2. Hands on experience with multiple technologies
3. Strong collaboration with other Deloitte entities like Deloitte USI , DELOITTE middle East
cons:
Cons of Deloitte India
1. Quite unstructured in terms of technical skills and capabilities. They hire or loan resources based on the capabilities required for projects won and try to manage with resources having little experience.
2. Pay structure is not up to the mark. 
3. Performance review process is quite centralised and depends to a large extent on yoir relationship with higher management.
4. Indian projects are mostly small in size with limited opportunities

I purposely left out my "Consultant" title on emails so superiors wouldn't judge me based on my title and judge me based on the quality of my work. Within a year I was then placed in Senior Consultant/Manager roles. However, I was receiving the same pay as a Consultant because of the promotion terms.

headline: Deloitte too big - employees just numbers
pros:
Great freedom. Everybody is responsible for its own career.  The social engagement at local level  or in whatever social group is awesome. 
It's is a great company to get the consultant mind, but whenever you get it, you may want to ask yourself about the differences between with in or with out.
cons:
the company is too big to be able to help you. You are only a number and will get a promotion or a raise only if you get well known, not if you charge a lot and / or do a great job. If you happen to have a project outside your region, or full-time. too bad.
Structures mean also, that if you missed that networking moment, you will have to wait a full year for any move forward.

headline: Great Career Stepping Stone but Awful Place to Work Long Term
pros:
- Invests in learning and training
- Flexibility to explore different industries and projects
- Ability to travel if desired (Pre-COVID), and keep travel points 
- Opportunities to get involved within the firm and community (volunteer to lead committees and lead events)
cons:
- Severely underpaid for hours expected to work (work life balance does not exist here)
- Management/Partners only care about the bottom line and thus will sacrifice individuals compensation/bonuses 
- Performance reviews are severely minimal (only based on 3 Y/N questions), biased, delayed and inconsistent
- Extremely high turnover rate, because even though it is a fantastic addition to a resume, many Consultants have the mentality ' just survive 2 years' to get to the next step in their career. This is due to the wide-spread lack of work life balance and under-compensation.

No connection with leadership

headline: Another Point of View
pros: This place affords you the opportunity to solve some of the most complex client problems.  You often work with with large teams and most of the time everyone pulls their weight to get the job done.  Talent really tries to focus on bringing in the best and brightest.  As you progress in your career, you also get an opportunity to counsel and mentor others as well as give back by teaching at Deloitte University.  My overall experience has aligned to a "work hard - play hard" approach to delivery of world-class IT services.
cons: Be prepared to adapt to the ever changing evaluation system where the rules change where it becomes increasingly harder to be successful.   In general, the performance reviews are fair, but inconsistencies exist.  The firm seems to reward sales and managed revenue, but doesn't always take into account hard word and effort that may lead to the recovery of a project.

headline: good
pros: good opportunities available throughout company.
cons: No cons to mention here.

headline: Consultant/Senior Consultant (Federal Practice)
pros:
Deloitte invests a lot of time and resources into training the best people. it provides a great mix of intense pre-job training, on-the-job training, and mentorship. Salaries are also very competitive in the first few years and get better as you move up. 

While every project and partner are different, overall there is a strong investment in their staff and a lot of opportunity to learn new skills and be "entrepreneurial" and find a good project / expertise fit that meets your interests/goals. You come out smater, better trained, and highly capable of finding a better next job. Or you stay, and make partner, and bank a ton of money.
cons:
Lots of hours, ambitious goals and deadlines, low margin for error, and a lot of stress. You will be working on projects you've never done before, with limited oversight, and high standards. If you screw up, you will have to stay late to fix it. If you screw up consistently, you won't be there long.

There is also a very broad skillset required - you have to present well, work hard, be smart, innovative, sell well, write well for proposals, analyze data, and juggle multiple ongoing responsibilities. If you underperform, you will not be able to find a team that will work with you and will ultimately be forced out - though there are a few go rounds. Additionally, given the diverse clients and importance of each partner, some projects will be very good or very bad.

headline: Great Firm, don't bother with Federal
pros: Deloitte seems to be a great Firm, Federal however, is not and it is very separated from the bigger Deloitte. I can't think of many pros in the Federal consulting space. Think about what you want long-term before you join and decide if you will really benefit from Federal (grunt) consulting work. Commercial consulting firms and industry jobs don't often see the value in Federal "contractor" experience (even if you are in S&O or Strategy). If you want a rewarding, impactful career in public service, work for the government.
cons: Clients often don't implement, and even the "cool" work is intensely boring. Consider how government workers are often looked down upon in our society (which is a shame)...well, in Federal Consulting you are below them, doing their grunt work, that they likely won't implement so you are dealing with a frustrating environment that lacks intellectual stimulation while totally wasting your time. Turnover is extremely high in the Federal practice and most at the SM or M level have only ever worked at Deloitte Federal so don't know the grass really is greener. If you are content doing mindless PowerPoint presentations all day while attending firm events in the evening and being surrounded by people who are doing the same mindless work, but feel the Deloitte brand makes them brilliant and better than others, then go for it! It's a cliquey, toxic environment, and frankly, a dead end.

headline: Deloitte Denmark
pros: High level of independancy in the Dansh organisation, exciting tasks (as long as they last) and great parties.
cons:
Working for Deloitte Denmark has been a negative experience. I have never before been in any other organization that has such a volatile and at all times changing approach to strategic leadership and handling of employees. 
Top leadership is openly fighting internally and initiatives launched for the common benefit for the Danish organization is shut down as quickly as they are started. 
During the time I have been working there, employees have been taken in and fired again very quickly, and it seems that there is no common alignment and back-up of in which strategic direction the company wants to move. 

Furthermore, there is an expectation that employees work 24-7 all 7 days a week. That would be fine, had the company been giving thanks to the employees, but it is not, and I have experienced colleagues break down multiple times.

headline: Stay for 2-3 years, then get out on your own terms
pros:
Deloitte is like any major corporate giant that you can think of - you may be the most creative, amicable, dependable team player, but in the end of the day, you're just one tiny cog in a huge mechanism. And make no mistake - the senior leadership (not the Senior Managers or your regular engagement Principals, but those who actually make hiring decisions) will have absolutely zero qualms about "making the difficult decision to separate" at literally an hour's notice. This is an up or out mentality, and that is perfectly fine, but this is probably the only place I've ever worked that has such little respect for its employees, once it sucks all juices out of them. 

That being said, I've met some of the most amazing colleagues here - people who have truly become my friends and mentors. These are the relationships I will take with me for years to come. 

So take this job offer with a grain of salt. (Also, they will tell you that you're part of just 1% of the applicants who get accepted. This is a lie. Don't drink the Cool-Aid.) Use this company to build your resume - you truly WILL grow professionally and personally, that is a fact. But you will work to the bone for it - crazy hours; always on call (don't believe the Flexibility and Predictability hype); the super-competitive people who will throw you under the buss whenever it may suit them. Deloitte is a shark tank - no more, no less. So take it as such, and make the best of it. Then, after 2-3 years, get out, and join the living in a smaller consulting firm, or elsewhere.
cons:
- Cut-throat culture
- Counselors are often inept and downright damaging to your career
- No accountability for leadership
- Salary decisions have zero visibility
- If you have a clearance, you are pigeon-holed into certain jobs
- Ratings are extremely subjective. Because most people in the federal sector work for the same client for at least a year, their ratings are usually done by the same person - which can be an awful idea, since it's extremely subjective and defeats the entire purpose of ongoing performance conversations (By the way, ratings are NOT shared with the employee throughout the year! You only get a composite "snapshot" at the very end, when it's too late)

headline: Great place to start your career... in politics.
pros:
- steep learning curve
- interesting and everchanging projects
- high responsibility and team commitment
- fast and clear career path
- good performances are acknowledged and sometimes rewarded
- diversity and inclusion are top notch
- people are usually very friendly, but it is important to distinguish between spontaneous behaviors to intentional ways to exploit someone
- adequate perks/benefits
- committed staff
cons:
- work/life balance is totally absent, it is either 12-14h/day job or find another workplace
- non-existent meritocracy
- extremely poor people management 
- partners & sr. Partners do not bring any value whatsoever 
- politcs, politics, and politics. Client &projects emergencies are non-relevant, if compared to “wrong mail salutations” to some specific people
- averagely, co-workers are either cocky-as-hell OR totally un-prepared
- management usually tries to drain out everything you can give in the shortest time frame possible, assuming you are going to leave the company soon anyways
- knowledge and information sharing is limited, as if asymmetrical information is some sort of competitive advantage lever
- compensation schemes are low and fixed
- people usually do not go hands-on on stuff, rather they try to turn everything into junior guys
- the company is overall fragmented and there is literally no communication, if not harmful when there is, among different service lines

pros: The company is really a good place to start your career with. Initial learning curve is good. Team dynamics are excellent. Lot of learning opportunities available at all times. One of the good pay masters.

Work life balance is entirely in your hands especially during busy seasons.

The appraisal takes good 5 months to reflect. Meaning the difference between your assessment period getting over and you start getting your new appraisal pay is 5 months.

Slow growth in terms of career levels. An employee with average skillsets will serve 4 years as consultant before he becomes a senior consultant.

Not recommended for lateral joiners.

headline: Manager - Deloitte Consulting
pros:
- Great resume builder; other recruiters and companies positively respond to the Deloitte brand (and to management consulting in general)
- Good empowerment in managing one's own career; you can work in any industry / function as long as you yourself make the effort to make it happen (i.e., network with leadership, contribute free time to project proposals, etc.)
- Generally collegial coworkers, especially at the more junior levels
- Interesting project work that takes you across different business problems and industries
- Strong management team that is steering the company is the right direction (from a strategic point of view); good job security
- Points / airline miles from travel and dining out
- Expense accounts are generally lenient (but depend on the client / project)
- Good health benefits
- Pension plan that vests after three years
cons:
- Unrelenting demands. Asking for free time to yourself is generally frowned upon. Everyone constantly feels like they need to show how hard they're working
- Uncompetitive pay at the Manager level (other consulting firms generally pay much more at this level), especially in light of the work demands
- "Nights / weekends firm activities": one is encouraged to sign up for additional "nights / weekend" work to show their dedication to the firm; these contributions are measured and evaluated at year-end
- Generally, travel from Monday morning through Thursday night; travel time isn't considered "work time", so travel happens during very early mornings and into the evening.  Only time to see family / friends is Friday evening through Sunday evening
- A lot of apathy amongst employees, especially at the mid-levels; publically, everyone chants "rah rah!" but privately, a lot of people aren't very invested in the firm 
- Very limited international work; most work is domestic US
- Terrible 401(k) match, something like 25% to the dollar

headline: High-quality firm that provides unlimited opportunities to those who are ambitious and ready for a challenge!
pros: Great people abound at Deloitte and I was impressed with the operations of the firm from day one.  Being such a large firm, the supporting resources (HR assistance, technical expertise for assistance on projects, etc) are quite extensive and I found myself constantly pushed to excel further than I had in the past.  It was a very valuable experience overall and my time at Deloitte was professionally rewarding.
cons: As with any large organization, the administrative and bureaucratic requirements can be a bit annoying (required training, endless counseling and goal planning, etc).  While not enjoyable, these are very minor cons and not something that would keep me from recommending the firm to anybody interested.

headline: Overworked and underpaid
pros:
Develop excel skills, decent 1st job, good for people that did all their homework in school and constantly asked "will this be on the test?"
The partners don't get rich either- they pay income tax in 29 states, meaning that $350k distribution results in take-home pay of ~$150k.  I guess that's a pro... at least they're not scamming the underlings for their own benefit, there's just not enough money to go around.
cons:
I averaged 75 hours (100% in office) per week for the year I was there.
Two weeks were over 100 hours
I worked weekends often.
Big 4 experience is no longer as valuable as it once was unless you want to stay in accounting forever.

headline: Great experience, good work, long hours
pros: Challenge, variety, experience. The big professional services firms provide a great environment for anyone to get a wide variety of challenging client-facing experiences. It looks great on the resume because alumni are widely recognized as experts in the job marketplact. Also, the mandatory sales work gives a good base for selling yourself to other employers. No one works at a large professional services firm for the money, it's all about the experience and challenge and long-term opportunities.
cons: Long hours, grueling pace. Everyone is paid on salary, except for the partners, who get paid for the money made in a given year. There is no reason for them to control anyone's hours of work. The official party line is work-life balance, but it will never get you anywhere. Senior managers and partners easily work 60-70 hours a week, all year round.

Success is attainable at the lower levels but making partner is extremely difficult, so long term career options can be somewhat limited.

headline: A great place to be challenged, and to grow
pros: Deloitte has a lot of smart, ambitions, motivated people working there.  This challenges you to be your best.  They invest in education, training, and networking.  In return, they expect you to deliver, consistently.  They provide excellent feedback on projects and overall performance, regularly, to help you improve continually.
cons: Salaries and benefits may not be as high as other management consulting firms, nor do they have the same name recognition as other more prestigious firms.  They're also diversified, so you need to be able to help sell their other services, not just management consulting.

headline: Amazing

headline: Diverse cross industry consulting experience in cost, business model, growth and innovation

headline: Brand is Career Booster, Luster Fades Quickly
pros:
-Fantastic training and initial "get up to speed" development courses help you learn the trade quickly
-Lots of bright people coming out of top schools join the firm and are eager and happy during their first two years
-Variety of different projects and ways to get involved
-Lots of networking events and nice offices across the country
-Good brand recognition
cons:
-Unclear, if not purposefully vague performance definitions
-Unreasonable and unquantifiable extracurricular involvement expectations
-Cut-throat, unfriendly environment
-Limited support for innovations and risk taking
-VERY difficult to move from one office/service line/practice to another
-The vast majority of projects at the firm involve implementation, not strategy
-S&O Consulting has a very audit/technology SDLC implementation/compliance/reconciliation focus despite information provided to new hires/prospectives connecting Deloitte to McBainGroup's strategy focus
-Easy to get lost in an ocean of people and projects with limited ability to find the island you're searching for due to PPD's protecting their turf and making their projects secret across the firm
-Limited cross-firm collaboration due to the above, PPD seem to be in competition with each other rather than helping their people and colleagues to grow
-VERY limited ability to work on international projects due to the swiss-verein "member-firm" structure whereby each country with the Deloitte name is actually a separate independent entity
-Easy to get pushed on to projects that are not at all what you want to work on due to internal inertia and lack of PPD trust in unknown consultants
-Clubby culture whereby various groups attempt to build strength and exposure

Disclosure: Received top performance awards for projects (2s and 3s), received applause award for performance, hold competitive/high exit potential Ivy league masters degree, experience in finance and consulting prior to experienced hire, Commercial and Federal exposure.

headline: Welcome to The Machine; Where Have You Been?
pros: There are some great people who pass through this organisation and there are certainly some innovative approaches to the advisory business.  The Deloitte Scholarship scheme is fantastic and successful applicants really are the Cream of the Crop.  The staff canteen in London is superb!
cons: New people to the organisation are discouraged from finding out about what others do - far too many genuine Chinese Walls and but also jealousy guarded lines of business.  So there is very little real cross-fertilisation and cooperation between colleagues in potentially competing teams.  Lots of people with very stressed expressions.  The expressed homage to work/life balance and genuine values is phoney.

headline: Prespective of Deloitte from someone with experience
pros: So far what I have seen is the commitment to promotion and career development.  Comparing it my previous software firm this is something that I have been looking for.  Support to move forward and merit wins not tenure. Secondly, from what I have seen Deloitte seems to take this whole process to another level and is very open about it with you. I am sure politics play a huge role with promotions however there is enough open process that you should be able to get a fair shake and not have to work the political side more than actually working.  One final note to move up you need to be involved in the sales process if you are given the title of Senior Consultant.  That also adds to moving up.
cons: Learning to navigate Deloitte seems to be a challenge that you needs to work through.  It is also the key to getting ahead.  The fastest you get this down and your network started the better off you are.

headline: Deloitteasourus
pros: Looks good on your resume. Also, hones up your acting skills. Great benefits. Tax has the potential to be what the rest of the firm is.
cons: Politics, back-stabbing, and a lot of old timers who do not deal well with change that sabotage any new comers. No collaboration. Everyone is on their own side. No progress. No trust. No team work. It's like kindergarten for orphans. Partners have favorites, favorites do hardly any work and throw everyone else under the bus. Management have no real positive leadership skills. Everyone walks on eggshells. I've never seen anything like it. Very disappointing. Better to just play along and not raise any issues. When you let them know the emperor has no clothes, it's you who has the problem and your life will become miserable.

My work is confined to the HRT department - specifically Workday Consulting and the work ethics and quality of consultants is gold standard. I had never thought of caring so much about work over my life, but I am at a point where it is more important than anything. If you work hard and smart it is rewarded as such, you can grow in leaps and there will be nothing that can stop you from achieving your career goals.
cons: Process definition is one part where Deloitte leads and lacks, it is time to take a hard look in how we need to achieve success in the market. Deloitte is dynamically changing and growing and processes need to also.

headline: No work life balance, unfair performance review process
pros: One of the most mobile job. Lots of opportunities for secondments in Deloitte in another country.
cons:
1. The work could be long and quite high pressure in busy season.
2. Performance review process is relatively flawed in audit. Too much power is given to the manager in team which makes the environment prone to bully and politics. 
3. There is no culture of supporting diversity though the company claims that they are all about it. There is clearly favourism toward the native. For example, it is noticable through the last 5 years that most of the international trainees either got fired or got their probation extended after the first 6 months. It might be understandable if some unfortunately doesnt perform so well but it's questionable that all internationals got the same problems about communication and attention to details as Hr at Deloitte claims to.
4. Senior staffs are just automatically promoted to asistant manager and possibly manager if they stay with the firm. This sometime leads to the fact that there are managers/assistant managers that don't understand /have no leadership skills meanwhile having the absolute power to retaliate their subordinates.

headline: Audit Senior Assistant

My coworkers are incredibly smart, motivated, and talented. As most people will tell you, the experience is what you make of it. If you're willing to put in the hard work, you'll (generally) see more of a benefit in terms of both pay and recognition from management.
cons: The culture depends entirely on the team of people you work with. Some teams are far better at creating a work-life balance and recognizing your contributions than others.

headline: Great Company But Careful Who You Align With (Consulting)
pros: Generally, one of the better companies out there. They seem to hire qualified folks so you normally don't have to deal with too many folks where you're wondering, "How did they even graduate high-school?"
cons: Politics plays a huge role. Align with the right folks, team, Partner or Principal, and you'll be okay. Do what you say and communication is key. If you start throwing people under the bus without being able to back it up, you'll find yourself looking for a new job.

headline: A truly exceptional place to start your career.
pros: Deloitte has an excellent culture that requires collaboration and team work in order to be successful. Additionally, the developmental programs for each career level and under-represented members of the workforce are best in class. Lastly, there is incredible diversity in roles (client-facing and internal) available to employees that provides talented professional countless opportunities.
cons: Deloitte places a heavy focus on "extra-curricular" activities. Although these are great opportunities for development, it does require additional work each week. Transitions between our Commercial, Federal, and international member firms is not transparent. Lastly, the pay structure has been adjusted twice over the past five years and still appears to lag other top tier firms.

headline: Great firm, lots of growth opps, strong brand name everywhere
pros:
- Free range to explore your interests/passions
- Constantly around talented and ambitious people
- Each practitioner assigned a counselor to help you grow within the firm
- Lots of social events in local offices/within talent groups
- Tons of perks like Alt Travel
- Great brand name
- Tons of training opportunities available (especially at Deloitte University)
cons:
The following aren't necessarily cons for me, but may be for some:
- Long hours, especially in M&A. Generally more laid back in Tech Strategy and GPS.
- Can be very political. It's pretty much up to you to network onto projects, so it can be hard for Analysts to get onto projects because they don't have a network built up (however, Deloitte recognizes this and doesn't stress utilization within first year at the firm)
- Performance reviews are very subjective (make sure your Manager likes you)
- Part of your performance review is based on internal firm initiatives. Adds to your hours (advice: find a fun initiative in an area you're passionate about)

headline: Good place to learn a lot - but few stay longer than 2-3 years

cons:
-Many projects were just repackaging old material with the new client's logo
-Consistent lack of leadership at the Senior Manager level
-limited opportunities to specialize in a field
-Many projects last years and it can be difficult to get off them, limiting opportunities and sometimes placing junior staff into the middle of political tug-of-war between partners and project managers
-Partners have a tendency to treat staff like commodities rather than people
-Deloitte doesn't have a strong reputation in the Strategy Consulting world, making it difficult to secure post-Deloitte opportunities in that area

headline: Great company with a lot of resources

1. Upward mobility.  If you work hard and do more you will get rewarded

cons: It's a private firm.  Your experience will be dependent on the group you are in and the Partners/Directors you work for.

headline: Good for networking bad for work life balance
pros: This is the company give you excellent networking opportunity world wide and provide you with the culture such that you become proactive in communication and soft skills and also know how to get things done. In terms of compensation they do really well compare to their competitors.
cons: The work was ok but the work life balance was bad. No time for me. The inside politics is on the top game as you have to know everybody to get your way.

headline: You definitely work hard...
pros: The learning opportunities are unparalleled. For nearly every engagement you are staffed on, you will be able to look back and think... "I sure learned a lot."
cons: Your career could be shaped (positively or negatively) by a seemingly random client situation where the best employee could be placed on the worst client, or vice versa.

headline: Veiled Enslavement
cons:
If you have been a consulting professional with ten or fifteen years of experience already, do not expect Deloitte to recognize that and hire you on your proper level.  They will put you at the bottom rung of their ladder and you then discover that the people who 'manage' you are grossly inexperienced in people-management.  You then discover that you are being used simply as a lowly temp as if you are in temporary staffing firm where you are literally railroaded into 'projects' you never interviewed for.  Unconscionable !! 

During the interview process going in you do not know that 'Managers' means people with only 5 years experience; and that 'Director' are actually people on your level - and there is no way to catch up to that level when you are placed on a relative low-level position.  

Long-term projects are closely guarded and impossible to find; resource managers are simply not invested in trying to get you the right project to your skills; 'networking' puts you in a position of almost begging and people know that you have a 'handicap' by being new to Deloitte and thereby try to just use you as a warm body.  

It is also a well known fact in the consulting community by now that Deloitte "over-hired" last fall without assigning new hires a project, causing many talented people to sit on the bench and then get terminated in the spring.  Several of the earlier reviews do resonate with my experience as well, such as 'politically charged' environments, and 'putting a warm body to a project', and also senior managers not caring enough in the development and growth of people under the 'Manager' position.  

It was absolutely a no-win situation for a seasoned, highly experienced consultant - there should be a warning or a disclaimer somewhere in their hiring process that makes it clear:  "Our ideal candidates are under 25".  It is the unspoken rule of their game.

headline: A little audit feedback...
pros: The acquired knowledge from on the job experience is priceless.  There are few jobs that develop a sense of autonomy, critical thinking, and problem solving, as an exposure to the overall audit process.  It also provides a unique chance to interact with businesses and industry leaders.  Networking opportunities abound.
cons: While there are programs in place at the national level to encourage a good work life balance, it is difficult to always maintain a good perspective because of the nature of the work.  "Busy Season" (October - March/April) is not conducive to a healthy personal life because of work expectations and demands.

headline: Good place to jump start your career
pros: Good project leadership, Good Career growth opportunities, Good people, benefits are good and if you can manage stress and plan your schedule well, there is a lot of flexibility. If you can push through the huge amount of work that will be expected of you, it is a pretty good company to work for and you will have grown a lot from a career perspective.
cons: Salary is a bit low compared to its peer. Worklife balance is a struggle for a lot of people. End year review is not transparent and not equal for everyone. Lots of politics are in play and different roles/project have different levels of visibility in the eyes of leadership. High visibility culture forces employees to take extra works or involved on multiple initiative at the same time, even if you are already full time on project. Leadership is open to listen about what you want for your career and help you, but does not always act on their words.

cons:
Work / life balance is very tough to achieve as often you are at the mercy of your client demands
Previously required ridiculous amounts of internal firm contributions, have scaled these back and now require only 1-2 activities
