headline: Play hard and work harder
pros: Deloitte really is one of the best places to work in terms of building a career.  You'll have the chance to work with some smart, driven people.  You'll be paid well, be provided with awesome benefits and have access to some pretty neat perks.
cons: Deloitte is an organization that is run by some of the smartest people in business.  As such, they expect a lot out of the people that work for them.  If you want to be a Deloitte Consultant, be prepared to work a lot of long hours.  Though, you'll get a lot back in exchange for that as I've referenced above.

headline: Good, but Inconsistent
pros: Career booster, have many different experiences and learn a lot quickly.  Great network, mostly great people that work here, at least at the junior levels.
cons:
No consistency moving from project to project.  The partners in the partnership each run their own project as they see fit, not in line with Deloitte's culture or core values, and it creates an experience where you can have a great project then a terrible one.  Be sure to build your network and stay with the people you know and trust.

Managers and Senior Managers often put profits over people.

headline: Environment that promotes anxiety and stress
pros:
OK salary, plenty of insight into multiple companies.
Centres of excellence are useful and more efficient.
cons:
Unpaid overtime, which is frequently abused.
Trainees are frequently made to work straight after study, preventing them from having the time to fully learn the material for their qualification.
Management turn a deaf ear to any complaints and expect staff to just get jobs done, offering little to no support.
Pressure on junior managers to increase their fees, but partners often overrule and agree lower fees.  Tenders appear to be won by lowballing, meaning the pressure is on staff to complete work in much smaller time windows.

headline: Work Hard Play Less
pros:
There's a lot of room to move. I should take more advantage of that. I've been on the same project for almost two years and I think I would be happier if I looked to work on different kinds of projects. 
Well-Being Subsidy is nice
Other fringe benefits are nice, but there are fewer benefits for people working in Project Delivery (generally federal) fields
Travel can be nice
cons:
Manager says Deloitte is a hard company to work for
Intense review of client work products-my team spends tons of time working on deliverable review. 4-8  hour conference calls to review deliverable content are not uncommon
Everyone works more than 40 hour weeks. Project employees are expected to work 42 hours per week. You can't take all vacation if you work less. Commercial sector and PPD track employees are expected to work closer to 50-60 hour weeks.

headline: AI Consultant
pros: Good environment with seasoned professionals
cons: Everyone is a one-man business, you've got to be focused. You build your career, Deloitte doesn't build it for you.

headline: Senior Consultant
pros: Pay is great based on the type of experience you have
cons: I worked on three engagements and hours are very long in all three engagements.  If you don’t have the network you are literally screwed at the round table and the way the feedback system is designed is very very confusing. Your manager says one thing and enter a complete different feedback in the system which is displayed as a scatter diagram which absolutely doesn’t make sense. As a result, you may not get the promotion. Even though some people at Deloitte are nicer and very supportive of you taking vacation or few days off but at my last my engagement I had to work full day during my religious holiday. And engagement team expected me to be online at 11pm when I went home. You may argue it’s engagement specific or based on client needs, I find it truly hard to believe that the engagement team couldn’t accommodate me for a day. I am looking to leave my job as I’m very unhappy about my hours and type of work coming my way.

headline: It was a great organization
pros:
Decent but expensive benefits, lots of PTO to counter the management initiative to burn out longer term employees. Great growth potential if you are willing to sell your soul to a partner, principle or director who has already sold their soul to their bank accounts.
Constantly evolving technology and practices.
This is a great opportunity to make some contacts with clients to further your future, just don't try and subscribe to the thinking it's a long term career opportunity.
cons:
Constant churn and burn driven by the current powers to be. Change is never fully thought out and followed through so it's sort of like swimming laps in a pool, but turning before you reach the end. Unreasonable expectations to work 65 - 90 hour weeks with no compensation beyond an occasional high priced meal.
Upper management and C levels are just that, managers and not leaders to those in the field churning out results.

headline: honest review

cons: long hours during busy season

headline: Good-not great
pros: Deloitte is a great company to work for, especially to start your career. You will be challenged, grow, and become or improve on being a very polished, well-rounded professional. Your career really is in your hands and you can shape it in so many different ways by projects you take, firm initiatives to get involved in, etc. There are so many fantastic people at this firm as well that it's easy to make friends, become close with your team, etc. Working in Federal is still fast paced, but projects don't typically have the burn rate of commercial nor the travel. Work may be less interesting, but there is a better work life balance overall (with some exceptions). Deloitte is great for a person who values independence, is ok being out of their comfort zone, likes to be constantly challenged, and can distinguish themselves and hold their own at a large company. Also, benefits are great!
cons: Most of the Federal work is not that interesting and can be staff aug related. PTO negatively affects utilization as do firm holidays, which makes no sense. Easy to get wrapped up in too many firm initiatives, especially if a project is slower and that can lead to burnout. That's less common now though with a culture shift. Federal Human Capital, especially female managers and above, can be extremely catty and mean. This firm  has a great culture, EXCEPT for the leadership in Federal Human Capital.  These women get away with bullying junior staff, choosing favorites, and have gotten away with ruining some promising junior staffers careers. There really aren't any female role models in this area of consulting any more and it's really sad.

pros: There are some very smart, motivated people you will meet here that will challenge you and teach you. Training facilities are very decent and there is a fitness subsidy.
cons: You have to make your life fit around the work, endless hours, and managers have no sense of boundaries, will call on your PTO/etc. Compensation not related to merit and sporadic layoffs are frequent.

headline: A fantastic place to work but I am not sure about the strategy
pros: Work/Life balance is excellent. Pay is also pretty good and tax free which is amazing.
cons: Deloitte is currently in a price war with some of the smaller competitors on the island and I am not sure we can compete with that. Losing a price war means that it is difficult to negotiate fees with clients as there are many competitors willing to step in.

headline: Don't save sex for old age - enjoy your life now and don't work for Deloitte
pros: Deloitte provides tremendous opportunities for career advancement, technical learning, and professional development.  The company pays for review materials for the CPA.  Deloitte offers over three weeks of PTO each year.  The company also gives generous pay, and a signing bonus.
cons: Fosters an environment of work - aholics.  Work - life balance cannot exist when the environment breeds the degradation of employees.  The generous signing bonus is to be paid back in full in the event you leave the company w/in one year.  This doesn't seem all that bad aside from the fact that you only receive half of the bonus (due to a 50% tax), but you have to pay back the entire bonus.  Managment is uptight about taking your PTO, which makes no sense at all.  Why offer PTO if you are going to make your employees jump through flaming hoops to take it??

cons:

- Frequent travel (this should be expected)
- Long hours (should also be expected)

headline: Deloitte Valuation IJV Mumbai - Management operating on short term interest, destroying department culture
pros:
Brand name is good
Good parking
cons:
Deloitte Valuation IJV Mumbai - Management is on short term contract and thus doesn't care about department culture. Management blindly favors couple of old employees and has awarded them back to back promotions and also has given them free rein to harrass and insult people. These Managers/ Senior Managers are very vocal in using staffing and appraisals as tools to intimidate people and humiliate their unfavored people very openly. This has also led to panic attacks and nervous breakdowns in many juniors. When some of the employees escalated issue to management, rather than taking any action against them, they were actually rewarded through promotions and good ratings every year. The people who filed complaints always end-up resigning because after filing complaints their life become even more miserable. 
Management is even allowing engaged /married couples to work in the same department (in violation of global policy), where they can affect each others and their juniors' appraisals/promotions very visibly.  In the historical meetings, the married/engaged couples had been advocating each others performances very vocally, which affected their ratings/ promotions and secondments very positively.  
Thus, its a really bad place for people who want to grow through performance alone. Humiliating juniors is a way of life here, which is rewarded by management.

headline: Great place to start if you're in the right place at the right time. Right now it isn't.
pros: Deloitte offers great exposure to all sorts of clients once you're out off college. However as you progress through your career you'll find yourself being overqualified for many positions (expecially manager level and above). Deloitte offers comparable benefits to those seeking a stable job. Depending on your office, you'll meet all kinds of people, most of them enjoyable. Trainings and the big 4 name gives you a pretty good career boost overall (that is if you're aiming for a future in the Accounting industry). Pretty good airline miles and hotel points I must add if you're traveling a lot. d
cons: Not enough focus to entry-level folks. Deloitte brands its image as being people centric but in reality it's all about the bottom line: keeping in line with partner's profits. When layoffs come, partners will care less about how much you've spend working and contributing to the firm and start switching into office politics to determine whether you should stay or not. If you're looking for achievement and career growth, you'll find yourself ending up in a pretty narrow corridor (as  you can see from their retention rate). I'd say, get a couple of years down your belt and get out ASAP.

headline: Mumbai office lacks good projects
pros:
1. Provides flexibility and predictability as well as work from home options

2. A handsome revenue is spent on project parties and office celebrations

3. People are provided free air-travel and stay for organizational workshops, relocation, deputation, hiring events as well as cab service for employees who work for extended hours.

4. Higher remuneration (more than competitors) for employees who travel overseas on deputation
cons:
1. Deloitte Mumbai office has not been able to diversify its project portfolio.

2. Revenues are solely being sourced from Integrated Eligibility projects that are delivered using age old (legacy Java) technology stack.

3. Deloitte overall forces its employees to do lot of unnecessary activities which are smartly coined as "Firm Initiatives". But these are essentially means to cut short revenue spending on auxiliary activities that would be performed by dedicated staff.

3. USI offices do provide learning/training opportunities, but they are eventually not fruitful due to lack of projects which leverage technologies for which training was provided.

4. Since this firm has limited number of projects that do not belong to a diverse set of clients, domains and technologies, Resource managers find it difficult to deploy resources on projects.

headline: Mostly positive but its still consulting...
pros: Competitive pay, bonuses, and benefits.  Constant training and opportunity to learn and improve.  Most colleagues and associates are solid and hard working.
cons: Travel constantly;  they say you can work on the projects you are passionate about however, the reality is you do what you are assigned... you get little to no real influence on where you are assigned.  Promotions requirements are not all that clear, just depends on whom you ask.  Worklife balance is so so - depends on the project and the lead. Politics are constant and competition is always apparent - you have to be good at selling yourself and talking your work up in order to be recognized. It doesn't end at project work, firm contributions are a big part of the job and take a lot of time and focus.

cons: Very cyclical work load, so there are slower times and then very busy times depending on time of year. The position is more program and event management  versus traditional recruiting so can be difficult to transition into from an experienced hire recruiting role.

The IT department is plagued by typical Indian managers and their worst characteristics. Before anyone goes with racism, I'm Indian too. I didn't even get paid for almost 2 weeks of vacation time I had accrued when I left.

headline: Completely disappointing consulting practice at Deloitte SEA
pros:

cons:
- Poor sense of professionalism & leadership capabilities
- SEA practice has poor tools & frameworks (highly misaligned with Deloitte Consulting in other regions)
- Lack of skilled senior leaders as most of those with extensive experience have left
- Low support of training & capabilities development for mid/senior-management staff
- Very terribly poor management of transparency - no idea what projects are in the pipeline & where support is needed
- Poor coordination of scheduling into projects & recruitment plans
- Top mgmt. is too focused purely on their bottom-line & chargeability (culture of 'cheapness' and wanting to cost cut every dollar they can)

cons: Depending on the engagement team you are on, some managers / partners can be abusive and don't care about your professional growth, there could be no work-life-balance. High school vibe in the Seattle office, cliques, politics can be excessive. Unless you have some Partners backing you up, progression within the firm halts at some point.

headline: Underimpressed by a mile
pros: Some very smart folks - the consultants were cool to work with
cons: We had a large client event coming up and instead of letting me get everything prepared (under 12 hours to go), one of the managers i worked for asked me to go on a liquor "run" so that the employees could all have a happy hour at the office. I was flabbergasted. No bonuses for admins. Snotty junior partners with big chips on their shoulders. The higher ups there are pretty cool, they've already made it and treat underlings well. But the young partners and managers trying to "make their place" are very unpleasant to work for.

headline: Sweatshop
pros:
- Travel perks for Senior Manager level and above, everyone else flyes economy.
- Can work remote but with major caveats, only for senior people and only if the Partner or MD you report to is ok with that.
cons:
- You will not have any life outside work. Junior people are simply told to work, while senior people are expected to be available whenever.
- Partners and MDs create fiefdoms. Nobody really cares about corporate policies such as diversity, inclusion, and code of conduct. Many conflict of interests are allowed to persist because Partners are ok with that.
- Politics are worse than in White House, you have to navigate whims and agendas of everyone around, nobody cares about what they are doing if it doesn't benefit them directly.
- It is impossible to move to another group.

headline: Good advancement and great people to work with

headline: Needs work
pros: Great enthusiasm about building business and serving clients. Great for variety or first career position i.e. new graduate.
cons: No direct contact or rapport building with internal supports like IT or HR which makes for a difficult transition.  Hard switch for career professionals because there is no defined roles. Roles will change depending on the resoures needed for client work.  Even if you're not a Business Analyst, you just might be for any given project. Clients and deadlines are often the priority over the employee and the is no such thing as reporting overtime. Demand for work can be very low at times and there is no real consistency unless you are on a long term assignment.  There isn't any interest in ensuring you are on a project. You will need to do your own networking to get assignments. Most teams that have worked together continue using the same people. Be very careful to know which location you will work for and if the team has had successful projects in the past (especially for design or technology groups).  Also, the benefit package is sub-par compared to other industry companies.

headline: Great place to work in Consulting, but can burn you out fast
pros: Great work culture, reasonable salaries, plenty of opportunities if you are dynamic.  Client centric culture.   Some of the best Team work, I have seen in my long career.
cons:
1.  Project Management being overly flexible for client needs brings more opportunities to Deloitte but put undue pressure on project team members, especially in fix bid projects.
2. Too much reliance on off-shore man power on consulting projects, results in undue demand of hours on team members working with the client in US.

headline: Extremely overworked with zero reward. Welcome to being a number not a human
pros: Some health benefits and standard 401k and pension
cons: You are a number, you could pull the company in a half million dollars and you are still a number. I will never work for another company that lays off 20% of its staff during the COVID. It’s not like we weren’t working 60 hour weeks on a multi million dollar project being extremely profitable to the company. You know you can give anything you want to a company like this. Literally your first born baby and they wouldn’t care. They treat their employees like numbers. At the end of the day your achievements mean nothing and grant you no job security. You can be laid off at any point they feel good to do so. They even give you 24 hours to leave the firm so no knowledge transfer. Even though I’m on of the original developers on a tool set they bought. Smart move lol . I guess some cheap labor in Indian can replace us  USA workers since they are ramping up the hiring in Indian.

headline: Best of the Big Four
pros: The best reasons to work for Deloitte is the equity you build in yourself with their brand name which can lead to more lucrative positions later on in your career. The people you encounter are top notch professionals and the training is second to none. Deloitte also has a commitment to diversity which is unrivaled by other firms. I have experienced this first hand through various engagements and it is very commendable.
cons: Your pay is on par with the industry even though you work for the industry leader. You also have to dedicate yourself to putting work before anything else.

headline: It is a great company to be work with. i have enjoyed working with them.
pros: The single biggest advantage of a large company is resources — of all kinds. Money-wise, while large companies do generate a lot of overhead, they also have the money to cover it. That manifests itself in all sorts of ways. If business slows down, you still get your wage at the end of the month.
cons: With all of those resources and processes come bureaucratic red tape. You’ll have a tough time having any ideas heard, let alone ones that are outside your pay grade that you think might improve “the company” as a whole. The larger a company gets, the more risk-averse it becomes — deviation from standardised practices is rarely tolerated.

headline: Great place to work and advance your career
pros: Deloitte provides opportunities to make large impacts with your clients and their business.  These opportunities will come earlier in your career than if you were in industry.  The pay and benefits are some of the best available and the people are some of the brightest you will work with.
cons: The consulting life style is not for everyone and the travel and time required for this job can be very stressful.  While the company does a lot to help people manage this and provides flexibility when possible, it is a reality that everyone must manage.

cons: Work and Personal life balance is a little poor.  Schedules change quickly and you have to be available at the drop of a hat.  Office politics and gossip is a bit of a problem, Deloitte talks about culture but some senior management looks down on those below them. Some employees will just coast and not try to do better.

headline: Strategy & Operations
pros:
-Interesting Clients
-Potential for interesting work
-Comradery 
-Depending on the project, good expense budgets
-Hotel and Flight Miles
-Enhances resume and opens doors
-You will become more adept in communicating and managing the business landscape
cons:
-You will work more than you can bill
-Your direct manager does not care about you given that there is 0 repercussion on how direct reports are treated
-You will only survive by continuously being submissive and sucking up to anyone who is more senior to you
-You will soon realize that client work does not matter as much as pleasing internal leadership
-You are told that it's an entrepreneurial environment were you can pick your projects,  but, the reality is that if there is a need, you will be forced to work on engagements that might last 6-9months or longer
-You will also be expected to work on multiple initiatives, which will require you to add another 8 hours of work per week besides your client work
-You will be expected to be available 24/7 and at your clients/managers mercy
-Work life balance is non existent - they provide "wellness initiatives" in order to check all the boxes in order to do well in good company rankings
-To do any interesting work, you will have to do massive amounts of pursuit work and basically work on non-billables so that you can fall in the good graces of someone senior, and when the need arises and the stars align, you are considered (good luck)
-Company will not help place you in industry if you decide to leave (aka Bain, BCG, Mckinsey)
-Company is large and you are just a #, you can easily fall in the cracks

headline: Prestigious but not that Great
pros: Working for Deloitte was pretigious, and being in the New York office meant that we were working with some of the biggest companies around.  Working for a smaller accounting firm might not bring the same opportunities, such as contacts with the finance and business world.  Such a large office meant that there were definitely opportunites to move within the same company; most people only think of Deloitte as an accounting firm, but they also have a large finance and consulting wing.  Deloitte also paid pretty well for the base salary as compared to some smaller firms.  The benefits were pretty good, and we got over three weeks of paid vacaction a year.  There were lots of layoffs this year, but Deloitte, to their credit, tried really hard to help us move to different parts of the firm before ultimately letting some of us go.
cons: If you are working on the business side, as opposed to accounting, you'll be working with the investment banks a lot.  You might be disgruntled knowing that you are doing a lot of the same work as your counterparts at the bank, yet making significantly less than them.  Even in the good years, your bonus will be almost laughable - and in the bad years, as this year, don't hold your breath expecting a bonus.  Also, as an accounting firm, your hours are at the whim of the client - you managers may be able to reason with the clients, but don't expect that to affect your hours that much.  You can't scoff at working well past midnight or on the weekends - and then other times you may have nothing to do for long, boring stretches of time.

headline: Audit at Deloitte
pros: Learn a lot and meet at lot of people working on client site.
cons: Employees at Deloitte have poor communication skills. They are awkward and managers are very rude and think they are better than everyone else just because of their role. You are treated like a number and have little say in where you work. It is a nightmare to book a holiday and leaving 'on time' is frowned upon. The office is dead with no sense of community (almost radio silent). A very depressing environment and does not suit your lifestyle if you have friends outside of work. Even leaving the firm was impersonal - resigned through the internal website and the HR team whom I did not have to meet once and barely communicated via email.

headline: Excellent place to work espcially if you start in the North East office.
pros: Yearly promotion, trainings, great software, good people (most of them), you are place into a leadership position very early in your career.  Support for your career development.
cons: The office you start in can make or break you because unrealistic expectations are set to complete audit staffs.  So If you start in NY there's an understanding that the standards or set very high and you are given the opportunities to build on your expertise and the option to move around until you finde your niche.  On the other other, if you start in Miami, you're expeceted to meet those unrealistic expectations and everyone ends up giving each other bad performance report.  As such, the Miami office tends to have a lot more stressed out, over work auditors.  Also the office is small compare to NY and thou D&T is a fair opportunity employee, the Miami office lacks that perspective.  Overall this is an awesome place to work and it can take you anywhere.  If you're thinking about starting your own business in a few years, it's best for you to get in the Tax practice.  If your focus is to be a CEO, CFO do audit.

headline: Great place to start a career and to continue it as long as you move around and find your niche.
pros:
Excellent training, especially the 3-year ACA. It's also good to be surrounded by very intelligent people, but this will vary depending on your service line. Most of the people I work with got a First in Economics and almost all have a Masters or PhD in Economics. It can be very stimulating to have varied problems and always have to be thinking of new approaches to unusual issues.

It's also relatively to move internally and internationally (although not as easy at this moment). I qualified in Audit then moved to Economic Consulting and so get to use my skills but don't have to go through the monotony of Audits. These are great for teaching financial skills, but I couldn't recommend it as a long-term career option - hence why I moved to a specialised area within Corporate Finance.

It's also useful to have a Big 4 name on your CV rather than a smaller practice. The scope for larger, more complex and more interesting projects is therefore bigger at Deloitte than much of the competition.
cons:
At the bottom it can be very dull with relatively low pay, but this is compensated for via the ACA qualification which makes you very employable. As you progress, you get more control over work hours and which projects you work on, but I've been lucky and many people can end up with tough hours and repetitive work.

There's also a huge amount of bureaucracy, as you'd expect in a large organisation. This can be a real bore and take up large amounts of time. Throughout much of the firm you're also expected to put your life on hold for work, but this largely depends on how good your managers/Partners are and how much they care - there's a lot of variety but most expect hard work and work life to be the absolute priority.

headline: Loved it
pros:
There are so much pros for working at Deloitte, it is quite hard to decide where to start.
First of all, the working environment is professional, and so they expect you to work hard. There are not room for slackers or coasters. Their compensation is however reflective of their expectations. Not only are you given the days to take a break and unplug, but also numerous benefits. Furthermore, starting off your career at a place like Deloitte will really help in the future to come as you pick up on things and learn not only about the different businesses, but also what it means to being someone with good work ethics.
cons: There might be people who might think that there is not work life balance at a big firm like Deloitte. And there is half truth in the statement that during busy season, you are expected to work hard and maybe past the 5 o'clock time. But when busy season is over, you are given a lot of paid time off to really get the rest you earned through your hard work. So it really depends on your personality. Do you like to work hard and play hard? Or do you prefer to just put in your 8 hours of work everyday? If you are someone who prefers the latter, the "work life balance" may be a con. But you have to understand that it is the nature of the business; A busy season and not a busy season.

headline: Regrets of a Type A Personality
pros: Strong brand reputation, ability to take on elevated roles and manage client relationships. Lots of talented, hardworking people.
cons:
Projects are generally understaffed and large programs can be poorly managed. Teams are over-delivering for clients but efforts and client recognition can go un-noticed by leadership and unreciprocated. 

My greatest disappointment is the amount of effort I have put in to deliver top quality implementations, yet the compensation is not effectively linked to performance. Extremely disappointing when you put so much effort to deliver at the next-level only to be underpaid at even the level below your impact. It's unfortunate that we are not more valued for the amount of revenue brought in from our clients. I should have focused more on getting certifications for a better exit opportunity....

headline: Busy season never ends for tech people
pros:
Flexible timing,
nice office
good gym, cafetaria
cons:
Less Salary
Way too much work
long working hours
no work life balance
micro time managment to its peak.

Example: Avg employee works 9hrs a day with 1 hr as his breaks. In deloitte, work is assigned based on hours and its expected to finish it asap. If you complete 8 hr of work then they will assign another set work to you. In short hard worker needs to work really hard. Avg time a employee spends in deloitte is 11hrs working (without breaks).

Counter effect is that you will left feeling unaccomplished and will be in a depressed state. Spend 2 years in deloitte and i garantee you will be scared to attend another interview feeling like you learned nothing. By the way most the tech they use is legacy so very little chance to develop skills.

headline: Endless opportunity and strong emphasis on performance on projects.

Employee benefits, compensation are generous for entry level employees relative to equivalent industry positions.
cons:
Project and firm culture value soft and technical skill sets differently which gives conflicting expectations as to what is valued in high performers.

Workload can be overwhelming at times if performance is not on par relative to peers

Firm culture rewards risk aversion over risk taking

headline: As others say, a fantastic place to launch a career
pros:
There are many opportunities to create a strong network that can assist you further in your career.

It is a large firm, and there are many smart, talented, and dedicated individuals with whom you may have the pleasure of working.

The compensation and benefits are very strong for people coming right out of college.

If your luck is with you, you may be staffed on a project that really allows you to shine.
cons:
It is a large firm and there are not always smart, talented, or dedicated individuals with whom to work.

If your luck is not with you, you may be staffed on a project where you toil in mediocrity.  I've seen many people (analysts/consultants) placed on projects not at all suited to their skills or with poor management.

It seems that a lot of your success rides on getting a good project with already-successful management that will support you and take you under their wing.

Attrition is high, but I suppose that is expected with any large firm.  I don't know for sure, as this was my first job out of college.

Work-life balance is difficult, as utilization expectations are high and internal firm contributions are essentially mandatory, independent of client work.  This can tip a person well over 2080 hours actually worked each year.

headline: Great place to extend your career, maybe not to start one or finish one
pros:
Great collaboration software and ability to interact with international community. Yammer, wikis blogs etc. You can interact with the CEO Giam virtually .
Giam is a great leader, really has his head screwed on right. Senior management are inspiring.
Support for women and differing ethnicities is fantastic
Great people to work with that have strong work ethic, commitment to quality.
Autonomous and supportive of new business opportunities.
Good social opportunities to make new friends especially for juniors.
cons:
When you get past the gloss there is little content supporting client facing operations, delivery of challenging work is due to skills of employees gained outside of deloitte. Juniors develop useful technical skills purely due to mentoring by senior staff on the job.
Partners promote those like them, very rare to have a technically capable partner, most are squeezers who take advantage of staff or management by spreadsheet types. Middle management at the partner level has a sleazy kind of feel. Those aspiring to be partner as well. 
No time allocated to take advantage of elearning opportunities..
So many meetings, performance management commitments and non billable "stuff" allocated by partners that you end up catching up on billable work and proposals outside of working hours.
HR is ineffective despite massive performance management culture, personnel that should have been performance managed out due to personality problems, abusive attitudes to counselees were not. Support for those that crack up due to the strain non existent, you are advised to call an outsourced employee assistance program. 
Employees chewed up and spat out. They bring in useful skills that atrophy due to lack of training opportunities and time to self educate, eventually they are no longer relevant technically. 
Expected to be married to the job, cult like culture. Very difficult to switch off due to the pressure of massive unrealistic expectations.work from home opportunities just brings the stress into the home and extend the working day into the night. If you don't have a mega supportive spouse don't think about working in a senior capacity there it's a recipe for divorce.

headline: Good Start for your Career and Good Brand for your Resume

headline: Things to be learned here, but no fun really
pros:
Reasonably good reputation that ought not to do the CV much harm. Almost automatic promotion / career progression in early years when joining as a graduate. Huge graduate intake means it is relatively easy / uncompetitive to get in.

Good client base and some varied and interesting work further down the line.
cons:
Conservative firm with the stereotypical accountant image and culture (boring, poor social skills) tending to pervade all service lines to some extent. It varies from place to place but most people who work here are conformist and not particulalry interesting, sociable or cultured. "Diversity" means a few candidates from BME backgrounds rather than any true variety of people.

Many of the graduate intake are tiresome individuals who did not give sufficient thought to their career choices until their final year of university. Unqualified for proper careers and not quite good enough for banking they then select a career at a Big 4 firm as Mummy and Daddy have heard of them, it cuts enough mustard with their peers, the graduate marketing materials were reasonably slick and it just seems that bit sexier than that grad scheme at whatever-it-was blue chip.

Having secured the job they really think they are doing something prestigious and worthwhile rather than entering on the least competitive graduate scheme going and destined for several years of tedium.

Real disillusion inevitably sets in a bit later when they realise what audit actually involves and that being an accountant is profoundly uninteresting to any body they might meet at parties.

At this point they tend to leave and find more interesting jobs and get some of their life back, hopefully before it is too late. This accounts for the huge turnover / attrition.

There is little point in staying too long as the reward scheme is purely geared towards a "jam tomorrow" possibility of becoming a partner (a possibility that is fairly limited, for most). There is no such thing as any equitable share of the profits on the way and your charge-out rate will be entirely decoupled from the cost to the firm of employing you. Rather it is designed to gouge from clients as possible and maintain the bloated remuneration of the partners.

headline: More than a job; Deloitte is an intense way of life
pros:
-Senior leadership is very approachable; unlike some places they don't stand apart from the rest of the employee population. Most make themselves available and are easy to talk to; most are not overly arrogant 
-Excellent training, both virtual and via Deloitte University in Dallas
-Smart, talented, and personable/friendly co-workers
-Continuous learning and the opportunity to really enhance your skills
-Lots of well organized networking and social events 
-It's a well respected firm, and makes for a great resume add
-Very good pay and benefits
-It's an excellent place for a recent college grad or young MBA to launch a career
cons:
-Unfortunately, the review written on Oct 10, 2012 about experienced hires still holds true today. Deloitte is difficult to assimilate into if you are an experienced hire, particularly one that has spent most of your career on the industry side
-Understand that working for a consulting firm is a lot different than being on the industry side; Deloitte recognizes this and tries to be supportive, but it can be a difficult leap when on a project and trying to do work "the Deloitte way"; there is little tolerance for views that don't align with the Deloitte way of thinking, particularly from those who have never worked in industry (which are most)
-The focus is more on appeasing the demands / expectations of Deloitte project leaders than it is on doing what's best for the client;  A lot of time is spent creating elaborate / complicated documents that the client will probably never actually use because they're not practical, but those are viewed as high value deliverables by Deloitte leadership 
-Deloitte is more than a job; it is a way of life.  Understand that joining the consulting division means lots of travel, long hours, and a very high level of intensity.  It's ALL Deloitte, ALL the time.  
-Client work is only one part of the equation. Everyone must engage in 'practice development' which is in addition to client work.  So you put in your 45-55 hours a week on client work (sometimes more) and then shift to practice development activities. Practice development is an important differentiator when review time rolls around.  Given the high caliber of co-workers, doing good work is a given. The only way to distinguish yourself is to take on numerous of these 'extra' assignments, which also helps increase your network.  
-Networking is beyond important.  You must get your name out there with people who have influence and can help get you staffed. 
-There are a lot of social events, which are also networking opportunities. Attendance is encouraged. As mentioned above:  it's all Deloitte, all the time.
-This is a young person's game unless you have spent your entire career in consulting and acquired the skillset early on.  Don't underestimate the difficulty of transitioning from industry if you are 35 or older, particularly if you don't have prior consulting experience. It can be a real confidence killer.

- You learn how to deal with different personalities as you work with different teams and you interact with the client frequently.
- great communication skills development
- A lot of resources available to get the job done.
cons:
- Low pay
- Long Hours
- 70% of the work you do in Audit is monkey work. 
- Poor engagement budgeting, which often translate to eating hours.
- Imprecise performance metrics

headline: Work culture like no other!
pros:
1. The best culture when it comes to Statutory Audit. I have personally experienced that even if you are a new joinee / fresher- your opinions are welcomed even in the toughest of situations. You are a part of the planning process as well (though not for huge audits). Further, there is a conscious effort to help you learn the latest amendments in laws or the best of the techniques to audit.
2. Coming from a mid size firm or a small size CA firm- the experience would be really good. Because the processes are so good that you yourself would become more organised while working. It helps you to be a better professional.
3. My team has a good work life balance - i only work Saturdays on extreme cases (say 1 saturday in a month - which is good compared to other big 3).
cons:
1. All the above Pros are highly dependent on the team you get. And moving from 1 team to another is a not easily possible when you are at the lowest level in the pyramid - Assistant Manager. Further, if you are on a hectic audit or have a pathetic manager (there are quite a few) - you wont even last 6 months.2 of my friends left within 4 months because of their managers.
2. They pay the worst compared to the other Big 3.
3. There are no offsites like EY or KPMG. Therefore, a 'fun' element goes out of the window.
4. The HR team is probably the worst  compared to the other big 3. They are non responsive (comparatively) and therefore the interviews are not a great experience.

headline: Not applicable
pros:
Well it depends mainly on the department which you are in. Auditing and Enterprise Risk Services (AERS) is known for its very high working hours. But a recently started Financial Advisory Services (FAS) has pretty much of a fixed working time.
Also, it has very high employee turnover because of work pressure(The Big Fours are known for employee turnover) The work culture is also not as comparable as I've heard from my colleagues in other Big Fours.
cons: The work experience that a person will gain won't be even near as you'll work in a small sized company/firm. Also, the seniors will be always ready to help in case of need. It has the highest number of companies for Audit in India, so it is on top of the table in India in Big Fours. So a person working there may get work exposure in varied fields. Also, as compared to other firms, where there are divisions for manufacturing, services, etc., Deloitte does not place it's employees based on above groupings. Hence, the exposure multiplies here too.

I was lucky to find a steady long term project to work on.
cons: Performance awards, Year end ratings, project ratings, all depend heavily on the projects you are staffed on. You may have to travel a lot. If you cannot get staffed on a project life can get very hard you'll have to compromise on the project you join. Salary is good out of college, but after a few years you might find you are being underpaid, and the only way to get a raise is to leave the company.

headline: Be prepared to work the grind and be at risk of burnout but high learning curve
pros: Amenities are nice - new building, nice coffee at Toronto headquarters. Brand will take you far and wide after you leave the company. You definitely learn the consulting foundations very quickly here.
cons: You are dispensable. They talk big about caring for their people but its all show - if you attempt to call out some issues with senior management (e.g., abuse of power, groupthink bias) they will make you pay. Conformity is the norm and it's very apparent with the increasing lack of diversity at the top. They make you jump through hoops to 'earn' a promotion that technically you've been performing for at a minimum 6+ months. You will be pushed to work crazy hours and beyond your mental limits working 6-7 days a week, 12+ hours a day, having anxiety over the onslaught of emails / work over the weekend. They do not actually care about attempting to align you to work you are interested in - even when the opportunity presents itself! I am grateful for the experience only because I hit absolutely rock bottom here and now I know what things to never subject myself to ever again. Also - drinking culture is heavy. It wasn't until I left that I realized how much it was a problem because the work is so stressful and you need to take the edge off. The pay is also abysmal and they know it - they utilize their 'brand' to suck you in to justify working you to a pulp and paying you very little in return. Come early in your career or get the consulting experience, learn the foundations and leave to better pastures in 2 years' time.

headline: Good for some, but not for me
pros:
Good opportunities for training (both internally and externally) and career growth.  From working there, I really learned to take charge of my career.  Despite being a Software Developer, I liked the emphasis put on skills such as communication, teamwork, networking, and industry knowledge, in addition to technical skills.  This has definitely helped me to grow and stand out in my field. 

Internal initiatives allow employees to explore new career areas outside of client work.  

Benefits are good, and so are the amount of available PTO days.
cons:
Work/life balance can be very poor.  While I worked on projects where this wasn't the case, I was working 80+ hours at my last project there.  There were even some weeks where I worked around the clock.  The last straw came when I had a conference call that went from 9pm to 2am in the morning, only to have my manager call me the following morning at 7am to see if I was up working again, despite the late night.  Mind you that I had to be at the client site that same morning.  It was a non-stop cycle.  I can honestly say that since I've left that I make way more money, work way less hours, and I'm able to enjoy other parts of my life now.  

In addition to client work hours, the internal initiatives were forced on all employees, and if you didn't do a lot of them, you would be evaluated harshly at Year-End.  This caused a lot of people to just "check the box", particularly with community service activities, where I would hear people constantly say things like they're just "getting their hours in".  I'm sorry but I feel like you should have a purpose for doing volunteer work, not just because Deloitte tells you to do it. 

There is a lot of favoritism at the firm as well, more than I've seen at any other job that I've had. I also felt that there was little to no respect for experienced hires.  Which was unfortunate because I found that most people that grew up in the Deloitte culture were very generalized and didn't have the skill set that experienced hires had.  Many of the young analysts were also very rude, arrogant, and disrespectful, and I felt that senior management encouraged this kind of behavior.  

I could seriously go on and on, but this highlights some of my biggest complaints.  If you're one that wants to live life, and not be chained to a job, be very very cautious before deciding to come to Deloitte.  I would also forewarn anyone who has a family (poor work/life, no regard for family duties), or someone who (like myself) is in a very tech-focused field (much of Deloitte's tech consulting firm is "process" based - they have very few software development projects).

headline: Very Demanding
pros: Deloitte Consulting is a great place to start after graduation. There is a great training/onboarding experience at Deloitte University short of no amenities. This is a great company to have on your resume for further experiences because everyone knows that their campus hires are some of the best in their class.
cons: Staff level employees are expected to do the majority of the work while upper level employees take most of the credit. Expectation to do firm initiatives and other stuff like networking is very demanding and can lead to long hours dedicated to the firm but not always to client work. This drew me in at first, but I like having my work and personal life separate. Not for introverts.

headline: Great compensation and good career opportunities. Horrible work/life balance.
pros:
The compensation is pretty good and being able to expense, get travel points, etc. is always a plus
Points deserve an extra mention here. Points for everyone.
Prestige - makes you feel pretty awesome working for a Big Four consulting firm
Some great opportunities for growth - if you know where to look and know the right people
cons:
Absolutely no work/life balance - everyone is expected to work more than the hours they are allowed to bill. 
Penalties for not making aggressive utilization targets, despite the above.
High expectations for extracurricular contributions, in addition to 60-80 hours of client work. (Read: Good-bye weekends.)
If you get stuck on a bad project, they are allowed to extend you at the expense of your career growth. (Example: My friend was extended so many times that she had to threaten to quitting the firm so that she could switch projects after almost a year.)

headline: Pros and Cons - but a good employer when starting out your career
pros: Starting as a graduate, it provides a great basis to learn and develop early on. The first year as a graduate is all about proving your ambition and drive so in essence be prepared to do the minutes and chair calls on the day to day. All of this sets you up to gain more responsibility and prove your worth - which can sometimes end up being a double edged sword. The better you are the more work you get. People are the true winner - lovely, down to earth employees
cons: Often left to your own devices with very little senior support - pros and cons to this but ultimately, it can be hard when you are learning as often you are in the deep end on your own. Luckily I have been on large projects with 15+ people but if you are on smaller projects, it can make meeting people quite difficult.

headline: Horrible place to be a partner in India

headline: Intestesting place to park yourself for a couple of years.
pros: Deloitte has a solid brand name that can be leveraged toward opportunities internationally.  The work environment is collaborative where the majority of the staff also work hard.  For those with the right background and a willingness to network, the opportunities are boundless.  The compensation at the lower levels is mediocre at best, especially when considering the hours of work that are demanded.  Compensation improves as you move up, with Partners doing well, especially given their limited skill set and brain power.  Deloitte will improve one's ability to present and sell without any true substance to back it up.  Intestesting place to park yourself for a couple of years.
cons: Quite honestly, the work is not especially stimulating.  What's so interesting about accounting?  The Partners tend to thing of themselves as Gods who's word has to be obeyed by lower level staff.  But, most do not have very impressive resumes: graduates of second/third rate schools, no experience with world class companies outside of the Big 4, closeminded individuals without a true world prospective.  They are lucky to be making what they do.  Much smarter and hard working individuals outside of the Big 4 make far less.  Regulation (audits, tax returns, etc.) give them a good thing.  Most couldn't make it in Investment Banking or Strategy Consulting...not smart enough.

headline: Consulting Manager
pros: Great opportunity to learn at a very fast pace. You have the freedom to explore a large variety of business verticals and solutions. Lots of very smart people and great networking.
cons: Very poor performance rating system. Yearly reviews are very political and biased, and not about performance. Very much seems like a "good ole' boys" club in my experience. If you have the unfortunate experience of working with senior management that you do not get along with, do not have same ethical bar or even male/female dynamic, ethnic and culture background clash, you are in for a bad experience, with little opportunity for recognition or growth.  You are punished for taking PTO, paternity/maternity/FML in the form of not being able to hit your metrics for the year.

headline: Good company to learn and start your career with OR end your career with being a partner

cons:

- Fixed career path and poor performance management system which does not determine the quality of work you are doing
- Managers want to manage without knowing what the ground work is!

I was a person with confidence, good work ethic, punctuality and professionalism before joining. At the time of quitting i left as a person with low self esteem not being able to cope up so much unnecessary pressure from the competitive environment.
Absolutely no work life balance. 
Not a friendly environment. 
Worst salary package ever

headline: Proceed...with Caution.
pros:
- Great place to start your career; ability to interact with senior management and some of the smartest people on engagements
- Learn a breadth of soft skills (PMO, networking, general consulting-based skills)
- Tuition reimbursement (full-time tuition assistance program for MBA and part-time tuition assistance program for other job-related Masters degrees)
- Rewards type-A, hardworking, over-zealous employees; wants to groom the next batch of PPDs and if you are one of the top performers on the PPD track, will be highly rewarded
cons:
- Hours required for "firm contributions," which really are just a matter of checking it off the box, adds no real value to yourself or firm (time is better off used to making clients happy)
- Not the best place if you are really looking to develop or enhance technical skill sets 
- Given ~25 days of PTO, but if you use all of it, you won't hit your metrics and won't be promoted
- Tedious mid-year, year-end, project evaluation processes
- Employees who are not aggressive and not type-A often get left behind, even if they are shining on project work

headline: Very exciting and a lot of learning oportunities.

headline: A great place to work and great people to work with!

cons: Flexible work schedules for administrative assistants are virtually non-existent, as is ongoing professional training.

headline: Your Mileage will Vary

headline: OK for freshers. Not a good choice for laterals.
pros: Compensation. Bonus payouts. Work from home( this is nit a pro actually. You will slog and your family life will suffer)
cons:
work life balance, stressful culture, Arrogant Managers, favouritism, useless firm initiatives, Extensive bench periods ( pretty stressful as you are asked to justify why the bench period was extensive),  focus on networking- now heres is the catch, DC India is a typical back office. You support consulting professionals from the US. You don't get to interact with the clients, where networking would have made sense. In a back office setting, networking is just another name for sychophancy. 

Bangalore office infrastructure is bad. I see people going gaga over benefits, but honestly speaking there are none. You pay for transport, food etc. Transport is below standard. The busses they use will give you back pain.

No recreation. The family day was joke. You were asked to pay for food! the list is endless.

cons:

headline: Competitive and collaborative at the same time, A bit like the TV show “Survivor”
pros: Variety of clients, projects and colleagues. You can do what you like at more senior levels, so long as you’re making money for the firm. Good learning for juniors (if you can swallow the low pay).
cons: “Cult of the partner”, a mutual admiration society where partners strut around and stroke each other’s egos like the cool kids in an 80’s high school movie. In team events and meetings it’s always about partner self congratulation, rarely about celebrating the people doing the great work. The competitive environment brings out the best and worst in people. The joy of helping clients and problem solving can get eroded by the internal jostling, turf grabbing and a few too many sub-par partners who got there because they had a good year, schmoozed the right leadership or created a “shiny object” (scaleable offering) and have since carved out a comfortable little niche to live out the rest of their days.

headline: Avoid the Project Delivery Model at all costs
pros:
Salary
Decent benefits in general
No travel
cons:
If you are under the Project Delivery Model,  you will be treated like a second-class citizen and a subcontractor of the firm. Here's how you're treated differently: 

1. 2 weeks of maternity leave for project delivery model employees vs 16 weeks for core model employees 
2. NO access to Deloitte University for project delivery model employees 
3. Lower salaries
4. Lesser benefits
5. Your employment is tied to a project. If you get rolled off of it,  you have 4 weeks to find another position or you're unemployed
6. They don't care about your growth or training unless it's tied to the project and what you can do for the client. It's all about the money.

headline: No work life balance, not a great career path
pros: Company keeps up-to-date with changing technological requirements
cons: I worked here for more than 2 years.No work life balance since focus is heavily on utilization. This will kill all the free time available to you. Also, you will think twice before taking leaves. On top of this, there is a lot of micromanagement also. People were generally unhappy while working here. Compensation is poor. Competition is tough. Promotion is extremely slow. In the US however, the story is completely different. For eg.you'll see that promotions happen within 1-2 years at the consultant level while in USI, people stay in the same rank for 3-4 years on average.

headline: Another me too consulting firm
pros:
+ Good work-life balance (I previously worked in a boutique consulting firm compared to whch Deloitte was not at all stressful)
+ Tax efficient compensation structure and reasonable benefits
+ Good training (in-class as well as online)
+ Senior management are "nice" people (generally treat others respectfully)
+ Some good colleagues - but limited to a select few. Most folks who are in India on secondment from the US are quite sharp. The average new recruit from B-school is also good. It is the ones who have been in Deloitte for a while who are quite below average.
cons:
- Unstable culture: In India, Deloitte was formed by the merger of 5 audit / consulting firms. Internally, there has been little integration and it is really a number of partner fiefdoms with varying culture. My partner's little empire was actually better than most, but that's not really saying much.
- Poor senior management: Most partners in Deloitte's India member firm seem to have got there by being part of the old boys network. Limited consulting competencies and even less of actual industry experience. So while many are "nice", but most are not "smart".  
- Lack of quality work: The obsessive focus on utilization means that any and all projects are bid for and accepted. There is no focus on building Deloitte's market position within industries. Whatever project comes our way, we'll do it. That is the modus operandi
- Poor quality outputs: Compared to my previous consulting firm, Deloitte's deliverable quality is terrible. The rigour in analysis, problem solving, hypotheses generation etc. leaves a lot to be desired
- Cookie cutter approach: On a post merger integration project I was part of, the approach was to look at Deloitte's previous similar work and rehash slides without paying adequate attention to the client's specific needs
- Wide disparity in consultant quality: The abilities at various levels (con, sr. con, mgr, sr. mgr, director) varies significantly even within the level. Have met some really sharp consultants and a good number of awful sr. mgrs and directors.
Deloitte (at least Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu India Pvt Ltd) is largely an audit firm with a consulting practice. So everything else is driven from that mentality.

headline: Succefully navigating a game of thrones
pros: I've been fortunate to have had really good opportunities throughout my time at Deloitte. I can confidently say that every project I've worked on offered ample learning opportunities and fascinating subject matter. This may not necessarily be the case for all who join the firm -- it is large and diverse. Having good support and positioning from the start has helped greatly.
cons:
I know full-well that Deloitte  can run you through the mill and spit you out downstream tired and drenched in frustration. The likelihood of such a result depends largely on where you've been positioned in the firm and who your immediate partners are. 

While the firm extols itself on how flat it is (there are only 6 ranks bottom to top) this increases the internal politics to sometimes byzantine levels. It can feel like a game of thrones as different "kingdoms" within the firm vie for human resources and clients. But this can also enable smaller players more leverage and more options than you might otherwise encounter in more traditional corporate structures.

headline: Deloitte Consulting
pros: Huge professional network to tap into, endless learning opportunities, variety of projects to work on, great total compensation package.
cons: Must grow your network organically, introductions are difficult and often you must be in the right place at the right time.  Must seek out your next engagement to work on, staffing is up to you and the network you have grown.  Utilization requirements are at 45 hours per week for billable client time, additional work learning and firm activities must be completed on your own time.  Total hourly wage is much lower than the to compensation agreed to when accounting for the extra time spent in the evenings and weekends to complete administrative work and firm activities outside of client billable time.

headline: If you have come to the USA looking for better work culture, this is not the place to be!
pros: Lots of free food lying around.
cons:
Lack of diversity. There is a reason companies focus on diversity so much. This place is a living example of not implementing that.

No growth both in terms of technology and personally.

You definitely don't choose your career at Deloitte(USDC) like they advertise.You shall work in what you are put into even if your offer letter says otherwise. 

Differences in outlook and responses between lower middle and upper management. They role play the bad cop good cop routine and does a horrible horrible job at that. So be very careful on how you communicate your grievances.

Less benefits and pay than core. Almost like a cheaper version of core.

Management is horrible. And owing to the fact there are so many Indians, you will experience the same politics you might have faced working in Indian offices.

They don't actually try to retain employees. Their model is to hire freshers at below par market rate (thanks to the challenging job situation currently) and will encourage you to leave so that they won't have to promote you. Then they will get another batch of freshers and the cycle continues. Just like how Indian IT companies work.

If you have come to the USA just to earn money in dollars, this is an option, but if you are here to escape the work culture back home and have that American experience and outlook to work, please please please stay away.

headline: Great experiences with a hit to work/life
pros:
At Deloitte you are surrounded by really smart people at all levels. There are a ton of training opportunities; it is clear the firm invests in its practitioners. Client projects are challenging in a good way, and if you play your cards right you can network your way over to the specific type of project you want to work on. There are also many opportunities to build small communities in this very large firm, including communities of practice in which you can develop skills to apply later on in a client situation. If you're bored here, you're doing something wrong.

Also, the firm has amazing benefits, and I think fair compensation for the junior levels.
cons: There are so many opportunities that you really need to learn how to say no. The firm will take as much as you give to it, or more. In addition to client work, practitioners are expected to help grow the firm through internal initiatives such as recruiting, business development, developing new solutions/tools/methodologies, etc. These are all really good opportunities, but they are a lot to ask on top of the 40-45 hours (Federal) that we are spending on client work. These opportunities become expectations the higher you get in the firm, and compensation starts to lag.

headline: Good place to work but only in your initial years.
pros: For a CA fresher good place to join, will get industry exposure. Have clients from all the sectors. Get to interact with top level management on a regular basis.
cons: Work life balance is not that good, increment also low as compared to other big4. More focus on documentation rather than audit or review.

headline: Good Company
pros: Learning Opportunities, Client Interaction, Perks
cons: Work Life balance, Travel, Work Hours

headline: The reality of Deloitte Consulting.
pros: Good for the career and resume. The downside of the firm is the constant travel, working more than 70 hours a week, having to do silly company stuff like QSMs, and participating in things that make no sense. I think it'll be good to have Deloitte Consulting on my resume but not sure if the hours and hours of work above and beyond normal workloads was worth it. The final line is that Deloitte Consulting is good for the resume but bad for your relationship at home, with friends, etc. because you are either traveling or you are working at home on the weekends.
cons: In the consulting practice it's a sweatshop and you have to work 60 - 70 hours a week. Constant travel. If you are not a long term employee then you are not in the "club" and therefore you are always treated like a new employee and not a long term team member. The firm has a way of treating people unfairly most often those who are new. I was just laid off and I must admit it was a complete surprise as to how it happened, why it happened and the timing. I am considering suing the firm because I believe I was laid off because of my age. I had been with the firm about 18 months.

headline: Tax Associate
pros:
According to top tax executives across the United States, the most important attributes of a tax advisory firm are service responsiveness, the ability to implement recommendations, a reputation for quality and how deeply it understands your business. Discover why so many leading companies of all sizes, private and public, rely on us as their tax advisor year after year. 

For all of its complexity, the area of international tax boils down to a single imperative: Reduce your global effective tax rate. We offer innovative international tax-savings ideas that align with your overall business objectives and the way your company operates.
cons:
Crucial to a multinational company's success today is the efficient integration of customs and international trade processes into its overall business goals, tax planning and supply chain management. Clearly, indirect tax savings — including customs duty savings — have a direct impact on a company's bottom line. But high-volume global traders wishing to achieve such savings face a host of challenges.

Our services help you navigate the complex maze of customs and trade rules, manage compliance risk, automate import and export processes, and maximize cost and duty savings opportunities associated with the production, import and export of goods around the world.

Difference in opportunities and growth in US vs India

headline: Beggar company
pros:
There is no single pro of this organization.I can't ever recommend this company to anyone.
There is no quality in any deliverable here people are working just for sake of finishing the task.
cons:
-NO WORK LIFE BALANCE
-CHEAP POLITICS
-TOO much inclined towards cost cutting
-NO coding standards and below avg in terms of market standards
-No processes are followed for testing and dev
-In some projects GIRLS LEAVE AT 1:30-3:00 AM in midnight and there is no cab service
-No escorts are provide even if you leave at midnight
-ONLY one small cramped cafeteria for thousands of employees
-POOR wifi which keeps fluctuating and sometimes even net outage happens.
-Employees are asked to purchase connectors for themselves if LAN connection is requested.
-NO voip facility
-No place to sit even for work employees need to sit on tables and PMUs(sometimes tables are also occupied)
-Coffee machines look like transformers
- No coffee and food when required
-In cafeteria also there is no place to sit.Employees have to wait for minimum 10-15 mins for seat(when you get seat then food is out of stock)
-No recreational areas - literary NOT AT ALL(oh...yes i remember one broken TT table on the rooftop without any proper shade)
-Water unavailable sometimes
-Washrooms are cramped - very small
-TOO MUCH WORK PRESSURE
-NO security
-No parking 
-HRs unapproachable
-FORCED TO WORK ON WEEKENDS WITHOUT ANY COMP OFF and OVERTIME salary
-EVEN after working for weekends you cannot charge for the billing 
-IF you have any issue hrs either will not pick the call or if you want to schedule one on one they are never available(always busy in some meetings)
-FOOD quality is also not so good and overpriced

headline: Career Pathing and development
pros: Deloitte's selling point for young hires starting a career is that there is a clear development path and steps to promotion if you fit into the mold of a consultant. Someone that can handle both the technical and functional aspects of the work while having excellent social skills. If you can succeed in that space the sky is the limit here, if your limit is to one day be a Deloitte partner, or make it to Manager before leaving for industry.
cons: Culture is tough in consulting generally and Deloitte is no exception. Firstly the culture is hegemonic and there is a prevailing groupthink dynamic. However, there is no immediate harm in going your own way and being yourself, but the people who advance tend to "drink the Kool-Aid" and have a similar view for how work should be sold and delivered. Furthermore, burnout is part of the bottom line calculation, this industry can grind you down if you are not careful and if you don't developed a good internal network.

headline: Deloitte - Great Place to Advance Your Career, Horrible Place to Maintain a Life
pros:
The best reasons to work at Deloitte include:
- Great reputation when applying for a different job
- Salary is competitive, especially out of college
cons:
There are many downsides of Deloitte:
- Work/Life balance is not promoted, you must fight for it
- There is no sense of team atmosphere; people look out for themselves
- The firm is very disorganized in planning engagement and evaluating personnel
- Partners and Senior management are not aware of the feel/atmosphere of the company and therefore do nothing to fix it
- Firm has refocused itself on tracking its employees, not for the benefit of rewarding, but rather to punish

headline: Hard-driven consulting environment of the Risk Tech Group, with little attention for employees' needs.
pros: Really smart people and collegiate environment.  There is a treasure trove of knowledge that one can acquire while working here and endless learning opportunities.
cons: Work-life balance is borderline absent, especially for employees in the lower strata of the organization, contrary to the company's statements.  Employees are referred to as "resources" and are treated as such.  Attrition rate is high as a result and that does not help the morale.  While there is good leadership at the top, some high-earning partners are permitted to get away with maltreatment of employees simply because they're making money for the partnership (not personal but observed on numerous occasions).

headline: Good for 3 Years, If You Come from the Traditional Path
pros:
- If you are in the right circle (i.e., in NY, Chicago, ATL, LA, SF), and you make friends with senior leaders, there is a lot of resources to pursue great opportunities
- In some areas (i.e., digital, human capital, M&A), they are innovative. However, the structure of the company (partnership) can be too consensus driven and fearful of risk
- If you are a direct campus hire, there is a red carpet laid out for you to go to business school (fully funded)
cons:
- Culture is a little stereotypical corporate + wealthy. They praise "diversity", but only if you are top-20 school, from a wealthy family, and a traditional background
- Learning slows down after 2-3 years -- at that point, you have to make your move (MBA, outside employer, startup). 
- Unsustainable lifestyle -- Consulting (like banking, PE, etc.) is a career that doesn't allow for W-L balance. If you want to attend your son's baseball games, don't make it a long term option.

headline: Lots of unused potential, lots of wasted potential
pros:
— strong name on the CV. it will open doors and work its wonders
— good social environment. some co-workers were extremely fun, helpful and great to be around and turned into good friends. I think that's a deloitte-pro and not always the case in consulting
— lots of high-potential people below Sr. Manager level. However, there's a caveat…
— ability to work on some high-profile projects and clients.
— if you do it right, you'll have a lot of fun and learn a lot while doing it. sounds like a good combination to me :)
cons:
— leadership and selected people. I think that overall there's a lack of vision where Deloitte and its Digital unit want to go, and it's showing. Lots of random projects / work to be done where many people are like "so… why are we doing this?", leading to some frustration below the coveted Partner slot. 
— projects. A lot of middle-manager mitigation steerco review board stuff apart from the high-profile stuff that's used as recruiting material. Not everyone will work on the high-profile stuff
— process is often put over people. that's not good, because often times the processes in place are just too old. 
— corporate bureaucracy. I know, Deloitte's a behemoth — but still: it's a valid point to list that often times stuff will just happen extremely slowly.

headline: I completed an optional-unpaid internship at Deloitte in Greece in the HR department.
pros:
-Beneficial and interesting e-learnings for new hires and new trainees.
-A multinational company with good brand name.
cons:
-I was performing menial tasks such as to bring my manager's coffee or to carry on 5-6 laptops for the testing of applicants. 
-I was excluded from meetings, interviews, etc. 
-No career advancement, my potential advancement opportunities were unclear, so I talked to my manager about the possibilities of staying and I tried to show my willingness to give my best. However, I was asked to stay additionally 1.5 months for an extended unpaid internship with unclear possibilities. 
- It was clear that this company and especially this department, replace a position with unpaid internships (continues to recruit interns for 1.5-3 months without hiring them). The employer is making money off of the unpaid labor and is taking advantage of trainees services for the benefit of the company.

International growth. Developed markets are growing slowly so more growth needs to come from emerging markets. The UK business is plugged into a lot of the emerging markets and employees have the opportunity to go on exchange programs to other offices. In particular, if you speak the language of any of these markets you’ll be a great asset to the firm.
cons: t depends mainly on the department which you are in. Auditing and Enterprise Risk Services (AERS) is known for its very high working hours. But a recently started Financial Advisory Services (FAS) has pretty much of a fixed working time.

headline: Recommend Deloitte
pros:
Working here is great for the resume and if you're straight out of college, most of your co-workers are young so it can be a fun place to be.  People are generally pretty motivated, have common sense, and social.  There are a lot of smart/accomplished people in management and are resources for knowledge and developing contacts.

Deloitte encourages you to use your vacation days and they also participate in community activities like Impact Day which is good.
cons:
The hours can be long.  Sometimes while at a client, it's Friday and you're ready to go home, someone will ask you to do something at the end of day which you know will take you several hours to complete.  There is a culture of always being a "yes" man, so if you care about your reputation and career, you have to say yes and get it done.  Once you make management, it's great to have staff with that attitude, but when you're the staff it sucks at times.  

Pay is not the greatest.  You hear people leaving the firm and getting huge pay bumps or there are people outside of the Big 4 in private who are doing the same thing you do but making more and working less hours.  You always have to remind yourself that you're not there for the money and that the paycheck/reward will come later.

headline: Deloitte Culture

They take care of employees' well being. Your leave will never be rejected by your manager. They are very flexible in terms of employee work timings. Good hike and other benefits.
cons: No cons are worth mentioning. There are always little ones like stretching work hours when you have to deliver to clients.
