headline: Good up until a point, but not exactly great
pros: Big resources, learn good skills, some of the work is challenging, and there are enough smart people to keep you stimulated. The PTO is generous and the firm pretty much shuts down during the holiday. The firm is truly Global, and we serve some big clients. Expense policy was nice when travel was a thing.
cons: Pay was good until the year before virus, now i'm staring at 3 consecutive years of little to no bump. Navigating a career at Deloitte is hard as politics reign supreme. Not too much voluntary turnover so getting promoted is becoming increasingly tough and cut throat. High work loads.

headline: Stay Away
pros: The company invests in employees development
cons: Toxic environment. Unless you have a good manager you will be dealing with a lot of politics. There is a false sense of being a team. I found people to the backstabbing I was warned I should have listened.

headline: Not a meritocracy
pros: Decent salary and benefits, flexible hours.
cons: Coming into Deloitte, 6 years ago,  I was naive in thinking that it really was a different organization - a meritocracy - that hard work, intelligence and good client relationships led to success. Unfortunately, over the past few years, I've realized that behind the veil and a layer below the surface, it's really no different. It is not a meritocracy. Promotions are not based upon how hard one works or how smart you are, but rather, like most other companies, "puffing-up" the right people.

headline: Overall great place to start career

Felt like upper management really did care about my experience as an intern and gave me a realistic idea of what my role would look like should I take on a full time position. 

Did gain valuable consulting knowledge in such a short time and felt that my work there prepared me for future opportunities

Extremely fun experience - several intern events and happy hours and networking opportunities. Many of us got lots of face time with partners/principals/managing directors and worked closely with our managers on our assigned engagements
cons:
Seems difficult to switch to another service line or location or even project. 

Huge emphasis on networking. It seems fun and easy when we're interning but could feel unnecessary once we have more demanding project roles 

Get the sense that many employees work well over 40 hours a week (even in federal, though commercial may be much worse) especially contributing to firm internal initiatives, although I do like that the culture emphasizes improving the company from within instead of pure client work

headline: Senior Consultant
pros:
•	Working for a firm with a good reputation and globally recognized brand
•	Working with high-caliber clients in high-profile, rapidly changing, and/or disrupted industries or sectors
•	Working on large-scale, global projects and initiatives
•	Learning about different industries, businesses, functions, and cultures
•	Acquiring and developing skills/experiences at a highly accelerated pace
•	Working with executives and managers
•	Working with highly intelligent, successful, and talented colleagues
•	Helping clients make better decisions about their workforce
•	Coming up with strategic solutions related to talent and change management
cons:
•	Consulting staffing model, which gives limited control to the practitioner over project, client, or work assignments, locations, duration, etc. 
•	Lack of consistency, predictability, and balance of work and life
•	Bureaucracy and politics of a large, traditional consulting environment
•	Sheer size of the organization, which makes it challenging and time-consuming to navigate, build relationships, and find opportunities
•	Expectations around contributing to internal firm initiatives in addition to client service
•	Occasional discrepancies between quality of services provided to clients and the quality of the same services provided internally within the firm

headline: A great place to train your soft skills and fill your CV
pros:
Lots of people to trade knowledge with.
Lots of areas of expertise to work on.
Low individual risk.
Focus on training and certifications.
cons:
A terrible place to evolve as a professional:
Long work hours( 10 hours daily for an average perfomance, lunch break is a joke; this is consistent and irrespective of the individual's performance).
People in the hierarchy usually have little to zero clue regarding the subject, they will hardly try to hear.(Knowledgeable individuals prefer to change companies for better compensation)
Efforts to manage lack of knowledge will have a negative impact on the individual that takes action.
These people will get credit of the work, even though their contribution could be negative.
The same people will take the blame away from themselves..
The individual is more dependent on the person above rather than its knowledge and effort.
More focus on the individual's profile rather than it's knowledge.
Flat and slow career path evolution; an indicator that productivity and knowledge is not appreciated.
Management communicates in a way that will bring the individual to a position unprofessional and unethical for discussion; apart from this management might try to make promises which cannot be fulfilled.
Management seems uncoordinated.
It is never clear who is the person in charge at company level, people will always avoid the responsibilities.
The firm's approach towards ethical and social matters feels as if it is only about the marketing.
Even though there are efforts for transparency with regards to evaluation and business matters, people are constantly working their way around to their benefits.

headline: Productive work enviornment

cons: Work day is very mundane and structured. There is little flexibility and acceptance for new ideas on ways to improve certain tasks. Hard work is sometime discouraged as they will not allow for overtime hours, even if you offer to do them unpaid. Furthermore, the communication between management and employees is quite terrible. Employees are discouraged from approaching seniors with questions in person and instead asked to email. The office is as quiet as a college library during finals week. I would suggest this job to someone seeking a steady job with regular hours, but not someone with a desire to learn and get ahead.

headline: Deloitte - great place to start, but don't stay too long
pros: Deloitte is a great place to start your career.  Good entry salary.  Many talented, intelligent people.  Many steps are taken to work and mentor individuals.
cons: Lots.  A job well done is considered consistently working 60+ hours.  People won't take the time to TRAIN their staff, as there's no where in the budget for it.  Budgets are unreasonable and while it's always said to never eat time, people expect you to eat time on their jobs.  Need more staffing resources.  Pay is decent, but can do better in industry.  "Ideally" you are supposed to work the most hours your senior years, but that's never the case.  Managers consistently work more than seniors, senior mgmt more than managers, and partners more than senior mgmt.  Frustrating environment overall.

headline: Deloitte is a great place to start one's career - alot talented professionals and flexible work schedule

headline: World class training, good benefits, smart people, and poor project placement practice.
pros:
1. The firm offers world class training in hard and soft skills. Makes one of the best places to work if you are just starting your career.
2. Offers above average benefits and compensation.
3. You may get very good exposure to a diverse set of industry projects
cons:
1. They will continue to hire new staff with same skills even if you are on bench for a long time.
2. If you have over 2 decades of industry experience, you will be the last one to get hired on projects. And if you are on bench for over a certain number of weeks, you will be asked to leave.
3. Its a game of musical chairs to get billable on client projects.
4. Work life balance - one of the worst in the industry. Expectation is - put work before everything else including family. 
5. Outside the firm exeperience is rarely respected. It is better to grow from entry level position to top. In other words - not a place to be for experienced hire.
6. Even if you are a very experienced professional , a junior colleague may write your performance reviews.
7. It does not matter how talented you are , if you are not well "networked" you will be on bench for ever.
8. Aggressive sales and poor execution of client projects
9. Very hard to please management. Quality rarely matters, where as quantity (number of hours, number of papers) do matter.
10. You are always compared to your peers for performance. If your peers put 80 hours per week, and you put only 60, you are rated "poorly performing".
11. You are always judged by your current numbers , and NOT by your potential or previous track record. 
12. Due to exorbitant growth, the firm has become a wholesaler of technology practitioners.

headline: Wonderful experience - highly recommend Deloitte (and consulting in general) as part of overall career path
pros: I worked on the consulting side of the house and you are always taking best practices in an industry and trying to apply them to real-life situations faced by your clients. In the Ottawa office, the projects tend to be of a shorter duration (a few weeks to a few months) so if you thrive on change and new challenges, it is ideal. You also tend to work with people who are highly motivated and that always brings an air of excitement to the work.
cons: Like all the big consulting/accounting firms, work/life balance can be an issue. I think the Ottawa partners were largely supportive of work/life balance, but there are times when you have to change personal plans (e.g. a day booked off) in order to accommodate a client's schedule. It's the main reason why I left Deloitte - and the consulting industry.

headline: For 1st year staff coming in straight from college
pros: There are a lot of great experiences that come through audit. you see a lot of things within companies that employees who have been there for years don't even get to see. High level information on how companies are run and function which makes a job straight out of college very interesting. As a first job straight out of college, it's a tremendous learning experience. however, they understate how much you would be working. the hours are insane and there is no "official busy season" - it could be any time or all year long. although they say they promote work life balance, they seem to work people 15+ hours a day and sometimes weekends. pay is not enough to compensate for this.
cons: The hours are very long and intense. You work in small teams, so if you do not get along with the team you are currently placed on, you have no choice but to stay with them. even though they advertise work life balance, there really isn't any. although they give you almost a month worth of days off, you really do use them, and its difficult to put them on your schedule because it gets booked. there is a lot of office politics of who favors who. if you get a bad manager or bad senior, as a staff, you suffer.

headline: A horrible experience
pros: Sometimes there is free food.
cons: It's hard for me to describe how unhappy I was working at the Deloitte US Delivery Center.  I couldn't sleep at night. I would sweat through my shirt every day just sitting at my desk. I was constantly feeling a 'fight or flight' response because I felt no trust in management and was afraid they were going to harm my career to accomplish their short term goals. The work environment felt hostile to me; I found managers largely unapproachable and that my peers saw me as competition rather than a teammate.  It was hard for me to find a project that was a good fit for me, most opportunities I was offered fell way outside my area of expertise.  I never once felt appreciated working here.  I got laid off over the phone because it was raining and the guy terminating my contract didn't want to walk across the parking lot in the rain.  Overall I would say my time at Deloitte was the most challenging and unsatisfying point of my career, and I cannot recommend this job to anyone.

pros: Good training in the accounting world.  The ability to fulfill the requirements necessary to be licensed as a CPA.  Nice friendly people to work with in the entry level positions

But for a woman (especially a single parent) with children, there is no consideration given to your personal life.  Out of state travel for prolonged periods of time might be expected which is not conductive to a balanced home life.  It was not unusual to work 80 hrs/week during the "busy season".

headline: Salary and work culture
pros: The senior management is trying to introduce a lot of change which will enhance the careers for all employees like providing a platform to work across service line, sign up to a mentor, etc. They are also promoting the agile culture in a big way. The salaries for offices outside of London are not benchmarked correctly i.e. the specialised function may only have a market in London however since Deloitte has chosen to base these individuals outside of London, they are benchmarked locally in terms of salary resulting in to a tremendously lower payscales
cons: The senior managers / directors are yet not open to the cross service line moves to enhance careers or allowing the staff to adopt the agile work culture. So you hear a lot about the vision but it will take ages for Deloitte to implement this solely owing to the senior staff who has been with Deloitte for years together and retain the old mindset.

headline: Deloitte Experience as a Fresher
pros:

Great WFH flexibility

headline: Great coworkers, with amazing support for career development and work life balance.
pros:
Deloitte treats its employees like human beings with families and obligations, not commodities that can be dispensed of when they’re no longer useful for their original purpose.  

I’ve seen multiple instances in which low performing employees were given years (literally years) to improve performance and were supported with coaching and training. I’ve also seen the firm actively work to find a different position for employees where their original position just wasn’t working for them or Deloitte.  

It sounds simple, but so many companies these days dispose of employees without a second thought.  Deloitte recognizes that they hired the individual in the first place because they have talent, and really goes above and beyond to make it work for both sides. This isn’t to say nobody gets fired at Deloitte, but I can guarantee you that due process was given before the axe came down.
cons:
=- Too much Administrative red tape at times.

- Administrative processes that seemingly have no purpose

headline: Travel Lifestyle
pros: Life is paid for when you're traveling. There are some smart people there that you get to work with and learn from. The culture and atmosphere is chill and relaxed mostly but serious and business when things need to get done. Work in teams and relatively transparent about pay structure at year end calls. Management listens to staff and takes their words into consideration. Lots of different types of projects and get to work with many different people from all over the world.
cons: The traveling lifestyle gets old as you get old. (80%+ of traveling dependent on industry and market offering) You may get lucky or unlucky when you first start on your projects depending if you get a long with everyone from your teams. There are a few not so pleasant people I've met at the firm, but mostly good people. The firm can be political in nature, like any big company, make sure you make friends with the right people and know how to network.

headline: What you expect out of a big 4.
pros: The pros associated with the jobs include flexibility, growth, opportunity to ask for different clients (rarely would you get them).
cons: The biggest cons are obvious, pay and hours. If you are considering a career in finance there are better ways to get that experience. This roles grows and leads to more project management than development of technical skills.

cons: Long work hours and high workload

headline: Pressure Cooker
pros: They'll let you work as much as you want.  Plus, no matter how late, someone else will still be there when you leave.
cons: The audit practice for public company audits faces a serious problem.  Keep audit fees the same, keep salaries the same, but perform audits at a higher than ever standard.  The PCAOB is applying pressures that clients and investors don't care about, so we audit in a state of paranoia.  The squeeze is performing these more detailed audits in conformity with regulator's standards, using the old revenue/salaries results in incredibly overworked staff.  I've never worked so much my entire life.  Worst of all, 88% of what you do each day, is documenting what you did the other 12% (actual auditing).  Not necessarily blaming DT, but any other business would look at their employees and see that working beyond 70 hours a week, even during busy season, is a call to add more staff.

headline: ERS Consulting
pros: Deloitte is a great company that offers good benefits, flexibility in determining your schedule and working remotely, as well as autonomy to execute on projects that you own. The people at Deloitte are generally helpful and there is a strong, positive culture at the company. You will be provided with many opportunities to advance, as well as network with other people within the company to navigate the work that is being performed within the ERS space.
cons: Salary is pretty low and once you get past the Sr. Consultant level, it takes quite a bit of time to move up in the ranks. Work schedule can be quite demanding during audit busy seasons. It can also be difficult to get off of IT audit projects when you are pegged as an IT Specialist within the Assurance workline.

headline: Management Consulting at S&O, Deloitte
pros: Compensation is at par with peers, work life balance is pretty decent and firm allows room for career shifts/changes to accommodate personal choices
cons: Compensation may not be the best in the market, career progress may seem a little slow

headline: Rewarding consulting experience coming out of an MBA program
pros: Very diverse opportunities - the firm is playing in all major industries and functions and is well known and respected in the professional services space for down-to-earth approach, great work ethics and focus on successful execution. National staffing model allows to align with the team and function of your interest. There are also plenty of opportunities to get involved in eminence or community efforts.
cons: It may be difficult to navigate complexities of working in such a large firm (although I got plenty of support from colleagues in my office). Practitioners play significant role in driving their own careers, which means expectation of choosing a few focus areas and proactively building your network in these. It may be difficult at first, but works as a great training for any future career.

headline: It's all about the selling baby.
pros: Impression of brand is good? to the clueless
cons:
WORK (Deloitte Digital)
-Quality of work doesn't matter at all - as long as you get an extension to the project
-Doesn't matter if there are qualified people to do it as long as there are bodies to be thrown at the project
-Pitches are MERELY cut and paste jobs - no innovation and no thought for the brief. Clients are just being sucked day and night. Poor fools. 

MANAGEMENT
-A joke really - both partners are abusive, talk only and do jack. Directors suck up to the partners and sleep in their 'privileged' rooms all day.
-Senior Managers (who do jack most of the time as well) leave to join larger tech companies to continue selling dreams. Just linkedin these jokers (in Singapore) and you will know what I mean
-Stay long enough and convince yourself enough that you are doing some form of work and you can prolly make it to director-level.


'Fake it till you make it' sounds so cliche but it's pretty much what you do all-day.

headline: Mental Health Discrimination
pros: Deloitte Consulting pays well but in return they want absolute loyalty and effort.  Depending on the level you are at, they expect 32 - 36 hours per week in billable time.  In reality they want 40+ hours and then on top of that they want 5 - 10 hours of "firm work".  Add to that, training time, (40 hours a year) and you'll easily be overwhelmed in short order
cons: Deloitte Consulting is cutthroat.  There's about a 20 - 25% turnover per year and they're quick to push out any who don't meet expectations.  The company uses a matrix form of organization which means you do not have direct lines of accountability and reporting.  I worked for them for almost 6 years, and was let go after being on a year of disability.  Multiple requests were made for accommodation and they refused any and all accommodations and then fired me by calling me on the phone and informing me of their actions with only 2 days notice.

THEY WANT YOU TO CONFORM, I find that leaders rarely ask or take feedback. If you are an innovator you will find yourself pushing through quite a bit of red tape to get anything done.
